CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderately high winds, estimated between 40 and 50 MPH, were blamed for downed power lines and a subsequent transformer explosion which killed three residents in the 5400 block of Acacia Avenue in San Bernardino, CA. The residents went outside to see what caused the explosion and a few small spot fires from sparks, and were electrocuted trying to extinguish the fires and help each other. A water line ruptured at the victims' house and 2700 customers also lost power because of the downed lines.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Santa Ana event caused areas of gusty winds in the mountains. Winds were blamed for playing a role in 3 fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0830 and 0930 PST, during which time a peak gust of 74 MPH was measured. High winds ended between 1730 and 1830 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high pressure ridge built along the west coast, along with high pressure building over the great basin, set up a pattern favorable for moderate to strong Santa Ana winds across southwest California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0230 and 0330 PST, during which time a peak gust of 64 MPH was measured by the spotter. High winds ended between 0530 and 0630 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: North to Northeast winds behind a trough of low pressure over Arizona and surface high pressure over the Great Basin brought moderate to locally strong offshore winds through and below canyons and mountain passes.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds knocked over a 70-75' tree with a 30 diameter trunk that fell on three units of a multi-unit apartment community in Glen Avon, near Riverside. Power lines were also down. No injuries reported, but the three units were declared uninhabitable and the residents relocated.|Five big rigs went down due to winds in the early morning on the 3rd in the area near Interstates 10 and 15 interchange in Ontario. Another crashed on HIghway 60 near I-15. No injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold upper level low pressure system moved southward from the Four Corners region into northern Mexico. Strong surface high pressure settled over the Great Basin and helped to bring strong offshore winds from the 2nd through the 4th of the month. The strongest winds occurred in and below the canyons and passes, causing downed trees and power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread urban flooding of highways and rural flooding of secondary streets in the Indio/La Quinta/Thermal area. Instantaneous rain rates were a quarter to a third of an inch per hour at times. There was also flash flooding of washes at the Whitewater River crossings (Dune Palms/Adams Street) in La Quinta.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold storm system dropped south from the Gulf of Alaska, bringing waves of precipitation and a few thunderstorms with pea-sized hail to the area. Upslope flow helped to increase precipitation totals in the mountains in general, but the upper-level dynamics caused the highest totals in the San Diego County mountains and surrounding areas. Large flows occurred in the Tijuana River and its tributaries. The snow level dropped to 3500 feet toward the end of the event, resulting in well over a foot of snow at many of the mountain ski resorts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Idyllwild reported a storm total snowfall of 15 inches. A spotter in Pine Cove reported a storm total snowfall of 20.75 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold storm system dropped south from the Gulf of Alaska, accompanied by a strong cold front packing gusty winds and moderate to heavy rain and snow. Snow fell as low as 1000 feet, with accumulations generally above 1500 feet. Winter Storm conditions developed in the mountains above 5000 feet where 15 to 30 inches of snow was reported by the end of the storm. Gusty winds also contributed to areas of blowing snow, further reducing visibility.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began in the Coachella Valley between 0750 and 0850 PST, during which time a peak gust of 72 MPH was measured by the Whitewater RAWS. High winds ended between 1350 and 1450 PST. A downed power pole closed a portion of Indian Canyon Road and a tractor trailer overturned near the intersection of Interstate 10 and Highway 111, but no injuries reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong westerly jet and associated shortwave trough moved quickly over the region accompanied by strong winds in the mountains and deserts, along with light rain over the coastal areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty winds were responsible for moderate damage in the Coachella Valley on the 7th. A power line fell in an alley in the town of Coachella, causing six homes to be evacuated as a precaution while power was restored. Two trees fell in the Indian Springs area, one landing on the hood of an SUV and the other blocking traffic in Palm Desert. No injuries or fires were reported with any of the incidents. The Palm Springs Tramway closed its mountain station early due to high winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold, late-season storm system dropped south through California, bringing a wintry mix of rain and mountain snow, as well as strong winds. In advance of the storm, winds gusted to 60 mph east of the mountain crests, causing some downed power lines and trees. Due to the inside track of the storm, moisture was limited and confined in and west of the mountains. Some areas even saw some lightning and periods of small hail in the post-frontal, unstable air. Snow totals were as follows: 7 to 14 inches above 6500 feet, 3 to 6 inches above 5500 feet, 1 to 3 inches above 2800 feet and due to the very cold temperatures, the snow level was as low as 2000 feet with traces of snow there. The very low snow level is significant for the month of April.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palm Springs Airport measured a wind gust of 45 mph on the 21st. The gusty winds were responsible for blowing over a single-engine, Cessna 172 aircraft after it landed Thursday afternoon around 1230 PST. The pilot, the only passenger, was not injured. Also, Indian Canyon Drive was closed due to large amounts of blowing sand near the Whitewater Wash around 1500 PST on the 21st. It had recently been reopened after being closed just a couple of days prior for blowing sand as well.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of storm systems moving across the Pacific Northwest was to blame for the windy conditions experienced in Southern California in late April. A particularly strong jet moving across the Pacific brought periods of strong winds to the mountains and deserts. The winds were responsible for blowing sand on roadways and even overturning one small plane.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds took down 35-40 trees at the Rancho Mirage Public library between late Sunday (8th) and early Monday (9th). The trees were mature, 15 to 20 foot tall mesquites and palo verdes. Nearby Thousand Palms recorded a wind gust of 40 MPH at 0300 PST Monday, while Thermal airport recorded a gust of 53 MPH at 2300 PST Sunday. No other damage was done to the library and no one was injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure aloft and strong onshore flow brought gusty winds to southern California, mainly in the mountains and deserts. These winds toppled several trees and at least one power pole, which resulted in a small brush fire in Palm Springs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy winds knocked over a power pole around 1530 PST on the 9th near Stevens Road and Via Monte Vista, according to the Palm Springs Fire Department. Winds were gusting in the middle 50s at many nearby sensors during the day. The power pole fell into a vacant lot where it started a small brush fire, which was contained within a half hour and did not spread beyond that lot. Power was out for around 400 customers in the area for about a day. No injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure aloft and strong onshore flow brought gusty winds to southern California, mainly in the mountains and deserts. These winds toppled several trees and at least one power pole, which resulted in a small brush fire in Palm Springs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: On each of the 17th and 18th, numerous record low temperatures (both max and min) were set in the Coachella Valley. Palm Springs and Thermal both broke records on May 18, previously set in 1994 with high temperatures of 76 and 77 respectively. The longest record broken was for Indio on the 18th with a high temperature of 74 breaking the previous record of 77 set back in 1948. The temperatures seen in this area during these few days were also about 25-20 degrees below normal for that time of year.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough and associated front moved through southern California each morning of the 17th and 18th. Rainfall was fairly significant for these systems, bringing around a half inch of rain to areas west of the mountains and up to an inch on some coastal slopes. Light snow even fell at the highest mountain elevations above 5000 feet. Strong onshore flow with gusty winds also accompanied these storms, however there were only a few gusts that reached advisory criteria in the mid-50s MPH, and no damage was reported. With the frontal passages, however, came record low max and min temperatures for numerous Southern California stations, such as Oceanside, Palomar Mountain and El Cajon.  A few single day precipitation records were also set.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds began at the Whitewater RAWS between 1800 and 1900 PST on the 15th and ended between 0400 and 0500 PST on the 17th. A peak gust of 56 MPH was recorded between 0600 and 0700 PST on the 16th.||These strong winds were responsible for two overturned big rigs along Highway 111 just south of Overture Drive. No one was injured, but officers asked high profile vehicles to avoid the wind-prone area of Hwy 111 and even began turning them away from the area.|Hwy 111 was eventually shut down for a time from Interstate 10 past Overture Drive for about four hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thermal gradient (105 degrees F at Thermal and upper 60s near the coast) combined with an upper low over Utah allowed for significant pressure falls, further tightening the pressure gradient, producing strong westerly winds. The strong winds were a factor in four separate vehicle crashes on the 16th and an overturned plane on the 17th. Winds were just shy of high wind criteria, but were oriented perpendicular to the roads where the crashes occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds in Coachella had kicked up a cloud of dust on the evening of the 16th. The winds coupled with the dust were blamed for a pile-up involving 5 vehicles and 3 semi-trucks. Visibility was reported to be near zero at the time of the crash around 1610 PST. Several people were taken to the hospital for non-serious injuries. Highway 86 was shutdown between Avenues 50 and 52 for several hours, reopening around 2000 PST that night. The Thermal Airport was reporting sustained winds of 20 MPH with gusts to around 30 MPH around the time of the crash.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thermal gradient (105 degrees F at Thermal and upper 60s near the coast) combined with an upper low over Utah allowed for significant pressure falls, further tightening the pressure gradient, producing strong westerly winds. The strong winds were a factor in four separate vehicle crashes on the 16th and an overturned plane on the 17th. Winds were just shy of high wind criteria, but were oriented perpendicular to the roads where the crashes occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds began at the Palm Springs International Airport between 1000 and 1100 PST and ended between 1700 and 1800 PST on the 17th. During this time a peak gust of 28 MPH was recorded. ||During the gusty winds, a small experimental plane flipped up on its nose after landing at the Palm Springs Airport. It flipped while turning to taxi on the runway. The pilot was the only passenger and not injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thermal gradient (105 degrees F at Thermal and upper 60s near the coast) combined with an upper low over Utah allowed for significant pressure falls, further tightening the pressure gradient, producing strong westerly winds. The strong winds were a factor in four separate vehicle crashes on the 16th and an overturned plane on the 17th. Winds were just shy of high wind criteria, but were oriented perpendicular to the roads where the crashes occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms moved westward across far eastern Riverside county shortly after midnight on the 6th of July. The storms affected the area around Blythe. A trained weather spotter reported very heavy rainfall with rain rates estimated to be approximately 2 inches per hour. The spotter also indicated that area washes were flooding, as well as streets in the community of Blythe.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of slow moving thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain across eastern Riverside county shortly after midnight on the 6th of July. Flooding of roads and washes resulted from the heavy rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three houses in Nuevo had minor flooding in the 500 block of West 10th, 28600 block of Central and the 28700 block of Reservoir. No one was forced out of their homes.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure aloft was centered over the four corners area of the southwest, which resulted in monsoonal flow into the region from the 4th through the 8th. Precipitable water values around two inches supported heavy rainfall from thunderstorms in the mountains and deserts. The most intense thunderstorms occurred on the 6th, when a few severe storms roamed the Inland Empire with strong winds and hail. Flash flooding was observed near Wrightwood and Phelan, while the Whitewater River north of Whitewater experienced a rapid rise in flow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines down due to wind in the vicinity of Perris and Romoland. Locations include Ethanac Road at Evans Road west of Romoland, South D and East 7th Streets in Perris, and the 27900 block of Washington Street. All lines reported down around 1400 PST on the 6th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure aloft was centered over the four corners area of the southwest, which resulted in monsoonal flow into the region from the 4th through the 8th. Precipitable water values around two inches supported heavy rainfall from thunderstorms in the mountains and deserts. The most intense thunderstorms occurred on the 6th, when a few severe storms roamed the Inland Empire with strong winds and hail. Flash flooding was observed near Wrightwood and Phelan, while the Whitewater River north of Whitewater experienced a rapid rise in flow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Whitewater River gage at Windy Point rose 1000 cfs in 30 minutes from 1830 TO 1900 PST. The source of the heavy rainfall was in the San Gorgonio Wilderness.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure aloft was centered over the four corners area of the southwest, which resulted in monsoonal flow into the region from the 4th through the 8th. Precipitable water values around two inches supported heavy rainfall from thunderstorms in the mountains and deserts. The most intense thunderstorms occurred on the 6th, when a few severe storms roamed the Inland Empire with strong winds and hail. Flash flooding was observed near Wrightwood and Phelan, while the Whitewater River north of Whitewater experienced a rapid rise in flow.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Gilman fire started around 1500 PST on August 6, along Gilman Springs Road east of Highway 60 near Moreno Valley. The fire burned rapidly though grass and brush to a total of 945 acres before it was finally contained around 1700 PST on the 7th. Highway 60 was closed from Gilman Springs Road to Jack Rabbit Trail and all trapped motorists were evacuated. No structured were damaged, but four hand crew members were treated for smoke inhalation, while battling the fire.  The cause of the fire is unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm trained over the area dropping moderate rain for approximately three hours. As a result, a channel overflowed, pushing 8 inches of mud onto SR 111 between Highway 195 and Mecca Avenue. The Palm Ditch Bridge was was covered in this mud, but was declared undamaged. ||Numerous other roadways in the area were closed due to flooding and/or mud flows as well.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwaves rotated around an upper-level low pressure system off the southern California coast on the 10th and 13th. This low provided the dynamics and moisture needed to set off elevated convection in Orange County on the 10th causing large hail, as well as other portions of the northern CWA which received heavy rain, flooding, hail and vast amounts of lightning on both days. Numerous hail reports of pea-sized to half-inch were reported on both days, though none of these caused damage. Several small lightning-sparked fires occurred with these storms as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong thunderstorms moved through central Riverside county during the morning of September 13th, and they produced gusty and damaging winds in the Chiriaco Summit area. According to a COOP observer, A 60 foot tall tree with a 3 inch diameter trunk was blown down by winds estimated to be at least 60 mph. The tree fell down and demolished a fence.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system along the California coast spread moisture into southeast California, and this led to the development of isolated thunderstorms over Imperial and Riverside counties on the 12th. The stronger storms developed gusty, damaging microburst winds which were sufficient to blow over semi trucks on Interstate 8 and knock down numerous power poles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with torrential rain developed across Joshua Tree National Park during the morning hours on September 13. Park employee estimates along with radar rainfall estimates indicated that at least 3 inches of rain fell in the park with the thunderstorms. Joe Zarki, Public Information Officer for the park, stated that extensive flood damage occurred to Park Route 11, the Pinto Basin Road, with loss of pavement in numerous areas. The Cottonwood Visitor's Center was flooded and parts of the Cottonwood Campground were washed away. No visitors or park employees were injured during the flash flooding and no vehicles were damaged.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system spread considerable moisture into southeast California, and led the development of scattered thunderstorms over Riverside county on the 13th of September. The moisture content in the atmosphere was very high and the thunderstorms produced flash flooding during the morning hours. Some of the flooding occurred in Joshua Tree National Park, fortunately there were no injuries or fatalities caused by the flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with locally heavy rainfall developed across portions of central Riverside county, from Joshua Tree National Park south to the Salton Sea. Radar estimated that at least 3 inches of rain fell in areas west of Chiriaco Summit since 6 am. The heavy rain led to flash flooding near the north side of the Salton Sea, east of Desert Beach. Law enforcement personnel reported that the flash flooding washed out a bridge on Highway 111 and Desert Beach Drive.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system spread considerable moisture into southeast California, and led the development of scattered thunderstorms over Riverside county on the 13th of September. The moisture content in the atmosphere was very high and the thunderstorms produced flash flooding during the morning hours. Some of the flooding occurred in Joshua Tree National Park, fortunately there were no injuries or fatalities caused by the flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with strong, damaging winds moved through the Desert Center area during the morning hours on September 13th. Fire Department personnel reported that a 20 by 40 foot patio cover at the fire station was ripped by strong winds. The winds, estimated to be in excess of 50 knots, also knocked down several palm fronds. The fire station was located just to the northeast of the Desert Center airport.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system along the California coast spread moisture into southeast California, and this led to the development of isolated thunderstorms over Imperial and Riverside counties on the 12th. The stronger storms developed gusty, damaging microburst winds which were sufficient to blow over semi trucks on Interstate 8 and knock down numerous power poles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall across portions of central Riverside county, including the area around Desert Center, during the morning hours on September 13. Thunderstorms started in the mid morning, and trained over the same area for several hours. Radar estimated that 3 to 4 inches of rain fell with the storms, and this led to flash flooding. At around 1220 pm, Department of Highways personnel reported that water was flowing across State Route 177 between mile markers 7 and 10.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system spread considerable moisture into southeast California, and led the development of scattered thunderstorms over Riverside county on the 13th of September. The moisture content in the atmosphere was very high and the thunderstorms produced flash flooding during the morning hours. Some of the flooding occurred in Joshua Tree National Park, fortunately there were no injuries or fatalities caused by the flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm Chaser Will Wilkens captured a funnel cloud on video near Perris around 1440 PST. There was a strong thunderstorm in the area when the funnel was sighted.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of shortwaves rotated around an upper-level low pressure system off the southern California coast on the 10th and 13th. This low provided the dynamics and moisture needed to set off elevated convection in Orange County on the 10th causing large hail, as well as other portions of the northern CWA which received heavy rain, flooding, hail and vast amounts of lightning on both days. Numerous hail reports of pea-sized to half-inch were reported on both days, though none of these caused damage. Several small lightning-sparked fires occurred with these storms as well.

The Windy Point fire started around 1753 PST on the 24th, west of the Palm Springs Tramway in steep, rocky terrain. During the firefight, State Highway 111 was closed in both directions. The fire burned 541 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on the 26th. At no time were any structures damaged or threatened and despite the rocky terrain, no injuries occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 2230 and 2330 PST on the 1st and ended between 1030 and 1130 PST on the 2nd. During that time, a peak gust of 81 mph was measured between 0330 and 0430 PST on the 2nd.|Nearby, a large sign was blown down on the 91 freeway near Highway 55.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An inside slider upper-level low pressure system, passing just north of southern California and then across the Great Basin, resulted in strong sustained and gusty northerly winds across much of the Inland Empire and Santa Ana Mountains. Several sites recorded sustained winds of 40-50 mph with gusts over 60 mph. Minor wind damage was reported with this event. A traffic light was blown down in Rancho Cucamonga and a sign blown down onto the freeway near Yorba Linda. A few small brush fires also broke out near Rincon and along the 15 freeway in San Diego County.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Highland Springs RAWS between 0415 and 0515 PST and ended between 1015 and 1115 PST on the 2nd. Between 0815 and 0915 PST, a peak gust of 64 mph was measured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An inside slider upper-level low pressure system, passing just north of southern California and then across the Great Basin, resulted in strong sustained and gusty northerly winds across much of the Inland Empire and Santa Ana Mountains. Several sites recorded sustained winds of 40-50 mph with gusts over 60 mph. Minor wind damage was reported with this event. A traffic light was blown down in Rancho Cucamonga and a sign blown down onto the freeway near Yorba Linda. A few small brush fires also broke out near Rincon and along the 15 freeway in San Diego County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Tonner Canyon RAWS between 0600 and 0700 PST on the 2nd and ended between 1100 and 1200 PST. During that time, winds gusted consistently above 50 mph with a peak gust of 60 mph measured between 1000 and 1100 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An inside slider upper-level low pressure system, passing just north of southern California and then across the Great Basin, resulted in strong sustained and gusty northerly winds across much of the Inland Empire and Santa Ana Mountains. Several sites recorded sustained winds of 40-50 mph with gusts over 60 mph. Minor wind damage was reported with this event. A traffic light was blown down in Rancho Cucamonga and a sign blown down onto the freeway near Yorba Linda. A few small brush fires also broke out near Rincon and along the 15 freeway in San Diego County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began in the Coachella Valley between 0950 and 1050 PST and ended between 1250 and 1350 PST on the 19th. During that time, two gusts of 58 mph were measured at the Whitewater RAWS between 0950 and 1150 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low pressure system dropped south along the Southern California coast and moved inland across San Diego and northern Baja, bringing 2 days of widespread heavy rainfall, along with gusty winds ahead of the precipitation and mountain snow. Rainfall amounts from the 20th-21st were 1 to 1.5 inches west of the mountains and areas below the snow level of around 5000 feet, resulting in an Urban and Small Stream flood advisory due to minor flooding on freeway ramps and other streets in western San Diego County. The month of November also ended around 300% of normal for monthly rainfall at Lindbergh Field, due in part to this event. Above 5000 feet, many areas received significant snow amounts, the highest being above 7000 feet in the San Bernardino County Mountains. Above 7000 feet, the Mountain High ski resort received 10 inches of snow with this storm, while the Onyx Peak and Wrightwood areas received 4-6 inches of snow. Big Bear and other areas between 6000 and 7000 feet received 2-4 inches. All of the areas above the snow level had chain controls in place for this event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Weather Currents station at Beaumont-Calimesa received 1.17 inches of rain in the hour between 1900 and 2000 PST on the 20th and a total of 1.61 inches for the day.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low pressure system dropped south along the Southern California coast and moved inland across San Diego and northern Baja, bringing 2 days of widespread heavy rainfall, along with gusty winds ahead of the precipitation and mountain snow. Rainfall amounts from the 20th-21st were 1 to 1.5 inches west of the mountains and areas below the snow level of around 5000 feet, resulting in an Urban and Small Stream flood advisory due to minor flooding on freeway ramps and other streets in western San Diego County. The month of November also ended around 300% of normal for monthly rainfall at Lindbergh Field, due in part to this event. Above 5000 feet, many areas received significant snow amounts, the highest being above 7000 feet in the San Bernardino County Mountains. Above 7000 feet, the Mountain High ski resort received 10 inches of snow with this storm, while the Onyx Peak and Wrightwood areas received 4-6 inches of snow. Big Bear and other areas between 6000 and 7000 feet received 2-4 inches. All of the areas above the snow level had chain controls in place for this event.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palm Avenue Elementary weather station in the city of San Bernardino recorded sustained northeast winds of 49 mph around 0700 PST on the 1st. A max gust of 70 mph was also recorded at that station at 0551 PST. |The Cal State San Bernardino mesonet station reported high winds between 0350 and 0550 PST. During this time, sustained winds of 40 mph were recorded along with gusts of 47 and 53 mph.|Numerous occurrences of wind damage near these stations were reported. An overturned box truck was blocking the slow lane of I-15 near Glen Helen Parkway.  Power lines and trees were downed near the city of San Bernardino. Power poles and lines were also down across 3rd Avenue near the Crafton Reservoir in Mentone.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: These events were the result of a large upper-level closed low over northern Baja, Mexico and featured four Santa Ana events, the strongest of which occurred in Orange County and southwest San Bernardino County with wind gusts 45 to 65+ mph and reported damage on December 1. These winds were strong enough to overturn several trucks, down power lines, reduce visibilities in dust and topple hundreds of large trees in Rancho Cucamonga (near Fontana, San Bernardino and Ontario), near the Cajon Pass along I-15. Rancho Cucamonga was declared a state of emergency by the State of California for the nearly 500 trees damaged. Overall, approximately 400 tons of debris was mitigated in the Rancho Cucamonga area.This area also suffered damage to the electrical infrastructure leaving many without power. As far as snow goes, 15 to 20 inches occurred in the San Bernardino County Mountains near Big Bear and Onyx Peak December 1 to 2, while only a dusting occurred in those mountains west of I-15. Much drier air moved into San Diego County on Saturday December 3, when the Santa Ana mountains and foothills had another surge of Santa Ana/offshore winds with gusts to near 60 mph and very low relative humidity. The final period of winds developed behind another system passing to our east on Monday, bringing wind gusts to 50 to 65 mph Monday night and Tuesday morning in the San Diego County mountains, and very low humidity.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ontario Airport ASOS measured a wind gust of 55 mph around 0300 PST on the 1st. Visibility was reduced to 3 SM in blowing dust due to the strong wind. |In nearby Rancho Cucamonga, the slow lane of Highway 210 at Day Creek Boulevard was closed to upright a semi truck. Fences and hundreds of trees were downed in that area, some blocking roadways. Another big rig overturned in the center divide of Highway 210 at Beech Avenue, blocking the HOV lane until it could be up-righted.

These winds were strong enough to overturn several trucks, down power lines, reduce visibilities in dust and topple hundreds of large trees in Rancho Cucamonga (near Fontana, San Bernardino and Ontario), near the Cajon Pass along I-15. Rancho Cucamonga was declared a state of emergency by the State of California for the nearly 500 trees damaged. Overall, approximately 400 tons of debris was mitigated in the Rancho Cucamonga area.This area also suffered damage to the electrical infrastructure leaving many without power. As far as snow goes, 15 to 20 inches occurred in the San Bernardino County Mountains near Big Bear and Onyx Peak December 1 to 2, while only a dusting occurred in those mountains west of I-15. Much drier air moved into San Diego County on Saturday December 3, when the Santa Ana mountains and foothills had another surge of Santa Ana/offshore winds with gusts to near 60 mph and very low relative humidity. The final period of winds developed behind another system passing to our east on Monday, bringing wind gusts to 50 to 65 mph Monday night and Tuesday morning in the San Diego County mountains, and very low humidity.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0351 and 0451 PST on the 16th and ended between 1351 and 1451 PST the same day. During that time a max gust of 65 mph was measured, along with several other gusts above 58 mph (including 2 of 61 mph and one of 60 mph).||During this time, power poles were reported down by Fox 11 News in nearby Yorba Linda. Around 240 customers were reported without power in nearby Tustin as well.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This upper-level low pressure system developed right on the heels of the last and became a closed low over the Northern Baja for 2 days, drawing moisture back into the area along with strong, widespread offshore winds. This system also set off intense showers and isolated thunderstorms with pea-sized hail (accumulations in Rancho Cucamonga and Mission Viejo), as well as several funnel clouds spotted east of John Wayne Airport. Most of the rain with this system was confined to Orange County, the Inland Empire and the northern mountains. Heavy rain was observed in Orange County and the Inland Empire on the 15th and 16th with locations there recording between one-quarter and one-half inch.  The snow level dropped to around 3500 ft., with accumulations of 3 to 8 inches there. Bear Mountain resort recorded 12 to 16 inches. Strong winds were also observed with this storm, especially on the 16th, which was a more widespread wind event than early December, impacting all counties, including San Diego County, with warning-level winds. Several wind gusts of 45-65 mph were reported in the Santa Ana Mountains, the Inland Empire and San Diego County Mountains. Several trees and power poles were downed, leaving many without power.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Highland Springs RAWS between 1316 and 1416 PST on the 16th and ended between 1516 and 1616 PST. During this time a peak gust of 63 mph was recorded between 1416 and 1516.|Several trees and power lines were reported down in the Hemet area of Riverside County shortly after this report.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This upper-level low pressure system developed right on the heels of the last and became a closed low over the Northern Baja for 2 days, drawing moisture back into the area along with strong, widespread offshore winds. This system also set off intense showers and isolated thunderstorms with pea-sized hail (accumulations in Rancho Cucamonga and Mission Viejo), as well as several funnel clouds spotted east of John Wayne Airport. Most of the rain with this system was confined to Orange County, the Inland Empire and the northern mountains. Heavy rain was observed in Orange County and the Inland Empire on the 15th and 16th with locations there recording between one-quarter and one-half inch.  The snow level dropped to around 3500 ft., with accumulations of 3 to 8 inches there. Bear Mountain resort recorded 12 to 16 inches. Strong winds were also observed with this storm, especially on the 16th, which was a more widespread wind event than early December, impacting all counties, including San Diego County, with warning-level winds. Several wind gusts of 45-65 mph were reported in the Santa Ana Mountains, the Inland Empire and San Diego County Mountains. Several trees and power poles were downed, leaving many without power.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds began gusting over 40 mph at the Cal State San Bernardino mesonet station around 0350 PST on the 22nd and tapered off around 0850 PST the same morning. During that time a peak gust of 56 mph was recorded between 0700 and 0800 PST. |Several gusts between 45 and 55 mph occurred.  A sustained wind measurement of 43 mph was also reported for the hour between 0650 and 0750 PST. ||Damages included a semi overturned on Interstate 15 near Fontana and another big rig overturned in strong winds on Interstate 210 near Rancho Cucamonga. A third truck was overturned on Interstate 15 near Devore by a strong wind gust. The driver of this box truck suffered minor injuries as a result.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This event was an upper-level low that followed an inside slider trajectory, passing just north of the region and providing gusty north-northeast winds on the 22nd and 23rd, but little in the way of precipitation. The hardest hit areas were the Cajon Pass (I-15 through the San Bernardino Mountains) and areas below that in the Inland Empire which recorded wind gusts in the 45 to 65 mph range, with at least one gust in the 70s. Strong winds blew over several semi trucks, one causing injuries to the driver. Several high wind gusts were also reported nearby. As the winds turned more northeast-east on the 23rd into the 24th, San Diego County was affected as well, though most winds did not exceed high wind criteria. Instead the mountains in that area experienced wind gusts in the 40 to 55 mph range.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began between 0551 and 0651 PST on the 22nd at the Fremont Canyon RAWS and ended between 1451 and 1551 PST the same day. During this time, wind gusts of 70 mph or greater were measured each hour for approximately 7 hours, with a peak gust of 75 mph between 0751 and 0851 PST. Sustained winds were 50 mph or greater during many of these hours as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Ontario Airport ASOS around 1000 PST on the 7th and continued off and on until 0530 PST on the 8th. During this time, gusts of 60 mph were measured around 2209 PST (7th), 2217 PST (7th) and 0510 PST (8th).|California Highway Patrol reported an overturned big rig on the I-15 south/I-10 east elevated connector at 0329 PST on the 8th. The connector was closed until 1026 PST due to high winds. The Ontario Airport ASOS reported a gust of 53 mph at 0253 PST.|CHP reported another overturned big rig on I-10 east just west of the Valley Boulevard exit in Fontana around 0637 PST. KONT reported a wind gust of 49 mph at 0629 PST nearby.|Another big rig overturned on I-10 near the N. Vineyard Avenue exit in Ontario at 1024 PST. KONT recorded a wind gust between 36 and 38 mph during that time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level shortwave trough developed over the Great Basin and moved south and east through Arizona, creating a significant offshore flow event for Southern California from the evening of the 7th through the 8th. Winds of 15 to 25 mph with gusts as high as 82 mph blew through the Inland Empire, Santa Ana Mountains and nearby canyons and passes. For this event, most stations in the San Diego County valleys remained below 50 mph with no damage reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 1900 and 2000 PST on the 7th and ended between 1100 and 1200 PST on the 8th. Several gusts over 60 mph were recorded during this time, with a peak gust of 82 mph between 0351 and 0451 PST on the 8th. |High winds began at the Santiago Peak mesonet station between 0030 and 0130 PST and ended between 0745 and 0945 PST on the 8th. During this time, a peak gust of 66 mph was recorded between 0119 and 0300 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level shortwave trough developed over the Great Basin and moved south and east through Arizona, creating a significant offshore flow event for Southern California from the evening of the 7th through the 8th. For this event, most stations in the San Diego County valleys remained below 50 mph with no damage reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palm Springs Aerial Tramway was closed around 1115 PST due to estimated 80 to 90 mph wind gusts. Around 20 people were temporarily stranded at the top of the station, but no one was injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful, elongated jet brought back to back storm systems (one on the 21st and one on the 23rd) through southern California with very strong west-northwest winds in all of the mountain and desert areas. Probably the most damage occurred in the Coachella Valley, where a prominent professional golf tournament was being held. Several stations in the upper deserts reported wind gusts over 75 mph, some reaching nearly 100 mph. The Coachella Valley experienced gusts over 60 mph, including the Palm Springs Airport, which rarely sees winds that strong. Multiple reports of power lines and poles down, as well as carports and signs knocked over. Many locations in the Palm Springs area experienced zero visibility in blowing dust as well, closing several major roadways. The second system on the 23rd, was nowhere near as damaging, but still recorded some impressive winds. |All in all, over 400 trees were reported damaged or down in the Palm Springs area and around $600,000 in damage for Riverside County during the event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Palm Springs Airport between 1230 and 1300 PST and ended between 1853 and 1953 PST on the 21st. During this time, two gusts over 60 mph were recorded with a peak gust of 66 mph measured at 1348 PST. The other gust of 62 mph occurred at 1646 PST. Several reports of damage occurred during this period. Between 1600 and 1900 PST, the wind was sustained at 30 to 45 mph. |Three major roadways through Palm Springs were closed due to zero visibility caused by blowing dust and sand. They were Indian Avenue, Gene Autry Trail and Vista Chino. Reduced visibility from blowing sand is believed to have caused a crash between a bus, a truck and a sedan on I-10 westbound near the Gene Autry Train exit. Four people were taken to the hospital for injuries from the crash. Power poles were knocked down on Gene Autry Trail as well as Palm Canyon Drive at Linden Way (also closed). Carports were knocked over by winds, crushing cars, at an apartment complex at Highway 111 and Escoba. Numerous power lines and approximately 400 trees were also damaged or knocked down in the Palm Springs area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Thermal Regional Airport ASOS measured a gust of 60 mph at 1442 PST on the 21st, but had been reporting gusts 35 to 50 mph from approximately 1300 to 1700 PST. |Bridges and wash crossings were closed at Washington and Adams Streets due to blowing dust and sand reducing visibility. |The Humana Challenge Golf Tournament at the La Quinta Country Club was stopped at 1322 PST due to the high winds. The leader board at the 18th Hole was blown over into the lake on the Palmer Private course. The main tent in the Bob Hope Square fan area collapsed. There was also damage to the vendor and event tents. No injuries have been reported. Several trees were knocked over or uprooted on the La Quinta course, while a few other courses had only cosmetic damage and blowing debris.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sustained winds above 40 mph were recorded at 0550 PST, with gusts of 55 mph reported at 0610 PST. California State University San Bernardino closed on the 27th due to the high winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Behind the powerful jet that brought back to back storms through southern California, upper level high pressure built back in over the eastern Pacific, resulting in strong northerly (offshore) flow over the region on the mornings of the 27th and 28th. The typical canyon/pass areas and Inland Empire received the strongest winds, both sustained and gusts. Many stations reported sustained winds over 40 mph along with several gusts over 60 mph. Despite the strong gusts and sustained winds, only a few damage reports came in regarding power poles and containers blown off of a semi truck.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS on the 27th 0651 and 0751 PST and ended between 1351 and 1451 PST. During that time, several gusts over 58 mph were recorded, including a peak gust of 61 mph measured twice (once at the beginning and once at the end) between the high wind interval. |High winds began again between 1751 and 1851 PST on the 27th and ended between 0751 and 0851 PST on the 28th. During that period, wind gusts were consistently above 60 mph and sustained winds were above 40 mph for the majority of the hours. A peak gust of 82 mph was measured between 0351 and 0451 PST on the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet station between 1130 and 1230 PST and ended between 1600 and 1700 PST on the 11th. During this time, several gusts above 60 mph were recorded including a peak gust of 71 mph around 1300 PST. Sustained winds of 40 mph or greater occurred from 1000 to 1200 PST and from 1600 to 1800  PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An amplified ridge over the eastern Pacific allowed a few upper-level short wave troughs to move over the region from the 11th through the 13th, resulting in strong, gusty winds and widespread light rain. These passing troughs culminated in a closed upper-level low over San Diego the 14th through the 16th. This cold, closed low dropped south and inland bringing widespread rain and heavy mountain snow to the CWA. |On the 14th, San Diego County received the highest rain amounts due to instability showers in the northwest flow behind the shortwave trough axis. Amounts were generally between 0.15 and 0.50 inches of rain, with around three-quarters of an inch on the coastal mountain slopes. Areas above 3500 feet received 2 to 4 inches of snow, with up to 5 inches at 5000 feet. The Riverside County Mountains received 1 to 2 inches of snow above 5000 feet, while the San Bernardino County Mountains fared somewhat better with a trace to 3 inches above 4000 feet and up to 6 inches around 7000 feet. |The system stalled out over San Diego for the 15th and 16th. The snow level dropped to around 2800 feet that day. The San Bernardino County Mountains came in with a trace up to 5 inches in the range from 3000 to 6000 feet and generally 6 to 8 inches above 7000 feet, with locally higher amounts of 12 to 14 inches in places such as Idyllwild and Big Bear City. The Riverside County Mountains had higher amounts with 10 to 14 inches above 5000 feet and up to 20 inches around 8000 feet.The San Diego County Mountains received 3 to 6 inches above 3500 feet, including 4 inches of snow in Julian which closed schools in that city on the 13th and 15th. Chain control was required in most mountain locations across the area above 3500 feet. California Highway Patrol even closed Interstate 8 near Pine Valley due to the snow and icy conditions. Rainfall was generally moderate and locally heavy ranging from 0.2 to 0.5 inches in the coast and valley locations, with locally heavier amounts up to 0.8 inches on the mountain slopes. Isolated thunderstorms with accumulating small hail and even a few funnel clouds also occurred in the cold, unstable air behind the front during the morning and early afternoon of the 15th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in La Quinta, near Thermal, reported blowing dust reducing visibility to one tenth of a mile or less. Winds at the time were sustained 30 mph and gusting to 47 mph.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Corona Airport ASOS reported visibility less than one-quarter of a mile from 0208 to 0256 PST on the 26th. Chino Airport ASOS reported less than one-quarter of a mile visibility from 0323 to 0353 PST on the 26th. Ontario Airport ASOS reported one-eighth of a mile visibility from 0453 to 0633 PST on the 26th. March Air Reserve Base ASOS reported three-sixteenths of a mile visibility at 0230 PST and one-eighth of a mile from 0248 through at least 0700 PST on the 26th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow marine layer resulted in dense fog during the nights and early mornings in the San Diego and Orange County coastal basins, as well as the Inland Empire, from the 23rd to the 26th. Numerous lifeguard and ASOS reports confirmed visibility less than one-quarter of a mile and even less than one-eighth of a mile.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 5 miles southwest of San Jacinto Peak reported storm total snowfall of 9.5 inches with a water equivalent of 1.33 inches. Idyllwild/Pine Cove reported 14 inches of snow at 5400 feet, which is their heaviest snow for the season.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep, cold trough, associated with its parent upper-level low in the Pacific Northwest, swung through southern California on the 27th, providing the CWA with widespread moderate to locally heavy rainfall and heavy mountain snow. The dynamics were also such that thunderstorms, some with up to pea-sized hail, were also observed. The trajectory of this storm system brought the brunt of the storm through San Diego county providing areas below the snow level and west of the mountains with one-third of an inch to slightly over one inch of rain. Some minor flooding was observed in San Diego County. Orange County and the Inland Empire received less rain, coming in with amounts up to three-quarters of an inch. The snow level was very low with this cold storm, dropping to between 2000 and 2500 feet late in the day. From this level to around 3000 feet had a trace to 3 inches, 3 to 10 inches up to around 7000 feet and up to 14 inches above 7000 feet. Several vehicles slid off the roads in the San Diego County Mountains as well, though no serious injuries were reported. On the lower end of elevation, snow fell as low as 1800 feet in Ramona, however the inch of snow melted later that night. Strong, gusty winds also accompanied this system, most notably in the San Diego County Mountains and the Coachella Valley. San Diego Gas and Electric reported major impacts with this system, including rime ice accumulations on power lines and structures up to a few inches thick.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Whitewater RAWS between 2350 PST on February 29 and 0050 PST on March 1 and ended between 0150 and 0250 PST on the 1st. During this time, a peak gust of 72 mph was measured between 2350 PST and 0050 PST. Winds continued to gust in the 50s during much of the rest of the day and evening.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built off the west coast behind a departing upper-level low pressure system, leading to strong and gusty north to northeast winds in the mountains, Inland Empire and deserts from the 1st through the 3rd. Winds commonly gusted over 60 mph in these areas. The winds blew dust around and caused damage in the Inland Empire and Lucerne Valley. Winds stayed below warning criteria in the San Diego mountains and desert, but many gusts in the low 50s were still reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0651 and 0751 PST on the 2nd and ended between 1051 and 1151 PST. During that time, sustained winds over 40 mph were recorded for several hours as well as a peak gust of 65 mph between 0751 and 0851 PST.

Winds stayed below warning criteria in the San Diego mountains and desert, but many gusts in the low 50s were still reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sky Valley Mesonet station recorded a peak gust of 72 mph at 0704 PST on the 2nd.

Winds stayed below warning criteria in the San Diego mountains and desert, but many gusts in the low 50s were still reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet between 1044 and 1144 PST on the 6th and ended between 1844 and 1944 PST the same day. During that time, several wind gusts above 60 mph were measured including a peak gust of 75 mph recorded between 1400 and 1500 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper-level low pressure system took an inside slider trajectory, dragging a strong cold front through southern California. This resulted in very strong winds in the mountains and deserts as the front moved through and only light precipitation over and west of the mountains. Behind the front, as the low departed off to the east, the winds turned north to northeast affecting the mountain passes, Inland Empire and Santa Ana mountains. Many stations reported gusts over 60 mph, several over 70 mph and even a few above 80 mph. This resulted in areas of blowing dust, flying debris and damage to a few mobile homes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds in the Coachella Valley caused several instances of blowing dust as well as some traffic sign damage and trees down. A street sign was partially knocked down from its supporting pole on Sunrise Way, near Gene Autry Trail. Palm Springs police also closed Gene Autry Trail between Via Escuela and Interstate 10 for much of the day on the 6th to be reopened by 8am the following morning.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper-level low pressure system took an inside slider trajectory, dragging a strong cold front through southern California. This resulted in very strong winds in the mountains and deserts as the front moved through and only light precipitation over and west of the mountains. Behind the front, as the low departed off to the east, the winds turned north to northeast affecting the mountain passes, Inland Empire and Santa Ana mountains. Many stations reported gusts over 60 mph, several over 70 mph and even a few above 80 mph. This resulted in areas of blowing dust, flying debris and damage to a few mobile homes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet station between 0000 and 0044 PST and ended between 0200 and 0300 PST. During this time, a peak gust of 71 mph was recorded between 0200 and 0300 PST. High winds were again recorded between 1544 and 1744 PST with sustained winds of 42 mph and a gust to 60 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong, cold upper-level low developed over the north Pacific, with a deep trough and strong, embedded jet extending all the way down to southern California. The main area of precipitation passed through the area the 17th through the 19th, providing widespread moderate to heavy precipitation over and west of the mountains. Areas west of the mountains generally received between one-half of an inch, and one inch of rain, through San Diego County came in somewhat higher, with some amounts near 2 inches along the coastal slopes. According to the Lytle Creek HADS gauge, approximately 3 inches of rain fell in the Lytle Creek drainage (mostly over a three-hour period), causing a 2 to 3 foot rise in the creek at a point where the bed was 25 feet wide. This rise in flow did not leave the creek banks. There were also several other instances of rocks and mud in roadways, but no major flooding occurrences. The San Bernardino County Mountains were the big snow winners with Arrowbear coming in at 28 inches, Big Bear with 12 inches and Wrightwood with 7 to 13 inches. The San Diego County Mountains were not far behind with Cuyamaca receiving 15+ inches, Julian with 12 inches, and Palomar Mountain with 10 inches. Snow drifts in the San Bernardino and San Diego Mountains were upwards of 2 to 3 feet in some areas. Most areas between 3000 and 7000 feet received between 4 and 10 inches, which when melted and combined with rain received up to 3 to 4 inches of liquid equivalent. One location, near the Lake Arrowhead COOP station reported around 5 inches of water equivalent. The snow level was particularly low with this event, bringing as much as 3 inches of snow down to around 2500 feet. Graupel was observed in Temecula, accumulating to around an inch at 1200 feet. The upper deserts received moderate amounts of rain ranging from less than one-quarter inch to over three-quarters of an inch at Phelan. Some snow fell near the desert mountain slopes as well, with Hesperia at around 1 inch. The lower deserts fared quite well, with one-tenth to one-quarter of an inch in the Coachella Valley and one-quarter to slightly over one inch in the San Diego County deserts.|Strong, gusty winds also accompanied this system. Numerous gusts over 60 mph resulted in power outages, blowing dust and traffic signs blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused mud and rocks to cover part of Highway 74 near Ribbonwood Drive in Mountain Center.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals for the 18th include: Pine Cove with 11 inches, Idyllwild with 10 inches and traces of snow sticking down to 1500 feet in Hemet and up to 3 inches at 2600 feet in Cherry Valley. The Palm Springs Aerial Tramway received 24 inches of snow, which closed the tram for most of the day on the 18th, reopening the morning of the 19th. |Highway 74 was closed at Highway 371 on the evening of the 18th between Pinyon Pines and Anza due to heavy snow and blizzard conditions. Chains were required between San Jacinto and the Coachella Valley and in several other mountain locations. Several traffic collisions occurred as well due to cars sliding around on the icy and snowy roads.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Whitewater RAWS between 2150 and 2250 PST on the 10th and ended around 0050 PST on the 11th. During that time, sustained winds of 35-40 mph occurred with a peak gust of 64 mph between 2250 and 2350 PST on the 10th. ||The Sky Valley mesonet station also recorded sustained winds of 42-46 mph with a peak gust of 63 mph between 2144 and 2344 PST on the 10th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough deepened down the California coast and swung through southern California on the 11th, into the early morning of the 12th. This system brought gusty winds and moderate to locally heavy precipitation to areas over and west of the mountains, as well as a few hundredths of an inch of rain to the upper and lower deserts. Precipitation for most areas west of the mountains ranged from one-tenth to one-half on an inch of rain, though Orange County received more rain overall than San Diego and Riverside Counties. Mountain locations received between one-quarter and three-quarters of an inch of rain. Above 6000 feet, a trace to 2 inches of snow was observed in the San Bernardino Mountains. A  couple thunderstorms with damaging winds also occurred near Hemet in Riverside County. ||A deeper upper low developed right behind the last and closed off before diving inland over southern California on the 13th. Instability ahead of the cold front set off several waterspouts and thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 13th. Lightning strikes and wind resulted in roof damage as well as downed power lines trees. The thunderstorms, along with the main area of stratiform rain, brought heavy rainfall amounts over and west of the mountains. Coastal locations received generally between one-third and three-quarters of an inch, locally up to an inch where the heavier thunderstorms passed. Several hundred cloud to ground lightning strikes were observed on the Coastal areas. The valleys of San Diego County and the Inland Empire received between one-third of an inch to 1.5 inches in heavier thunderstorms and along the coastal mountain slopes. Some urban flooding was observed, including a stranded motorist in standing water near Ontario and another truck pulled out of a flooded riverbed near San Bernardino. Some lower mountain locations in San Diego County received up to 2 inches of rainfall. Moderately low snow levels near 4000 feet dropped heavy snow in the mountains as well, especially in the higher elevations of San Bernardino and Riverside Counties. San Diego County received 1 to 5 inches between 4000 and 5000 feet and up to 10 inches near Mt. Laguna. Riverside County was similar with 6 to 10 inches of snow above 5500 feet. San Bernardino County was the big snow winner with several locations reporting 10 to 14 inches above 6000 feet and a max of 16 inches of snow at Arrowbear Lake.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds from a thunderstorm in the Hemet area ripped off a 30-foot section of a mobile home carport awning and damaged part of the roof near the intersection of Gilbert and Chambers Streets. A piece of the awning landed roughly 150 yards away at Diamond Valley Middle School. A tree at the school was also damaged. Based on spotter reports and a survey of the area along with radar data, it was determined to be a possible gustnado with estimated gusts to 65 mph. Small debris was|found near McSweeny Elementary School. The extent of damage is unknown, but time was based on another report of a thunderstorm in the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snowfall totals for the 13th-14th include 12 inches at Mt. San Jacinto, 10 inches  in Idyllwild and 6 inches in Pine Cove.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet station between 1445 and 1545 PST on the 23rd and occurred off and on through on the 26th. Several gusts over 58 mph were recorded between 1500 PST on the 23rd through 0000 PST on the 24th. A peak gust of 69 mph was measured between 2244 and 2344 PST on the 23rd. High winds occurred again late evening on the 25th with a peak gust of 73 mph around 2200 PST and early afternoon on the 26th with a peak gust of 66 mph around 1300 PST.||High winds also occurred at the Whitewater RAWS with a peak gust of 60 mph occurring between 2250 and 2350 PST on the 23rd as well as another gust to 59 mph between 0750 and 0850 PST on the 25th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty southwesterly occurred over the mountains and desert slopes ahead of a low pressure system that moved through southern California and northern Baja on the 24th/25th. No damage was reported with these winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Sky Valley mesonet station from 2230 PST on the 1st through 0200 PST on the 2nd with a peak gust of 73 mph measured around 0000 PST on the 2nd. The station also recorded high winds between 1444 and 1800 PST on the 3rd with a peak gust of 62 mph. During these times, there were several instances of sustained winds over 40 mph. Sporadic gusts 55-60 mph occurred through around 1700 PST on the 4th. ||High winds occurred at the Whitewater RAWS between approximately 0100 and 0400 PST on the 2nd with a peak gust of 65 mph. Sustained winds 35-40 mph with gusts in the 50s continued through approximately 0200 PST on the 3rd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough in place over Southern California resulted in gusty surface winds in the mountains and deserts, especially through the passes and canyons. Winds were often sustained over 40 mph and gusting at or above 60 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 86 year old male was hospitalized for a heat-related illness on May 12th near Mecca in the Salton Sea desert area of the Coachella Valley. The Riverside County Health Department confirmed his death on May 18 as heat-related. No mental issues were noted.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure was in place over the region from the 11th through the 14th, creating a warming trend with inland temperatures 5 to 15 degrees above normal for that time of year. Temperatures in the lower deserts ranged from 97 up to 105 during these few days. A heat-related death was reported and confirmed due to this event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds first gusted over 45 mph at the Sky Valley mesonet around 1600 PST on the 17th and continued through 1200 PST on the 18th. The peak gust of 74 mph occurred around 0000 PST on the 18th. ||Winds first gusted over 45 mph at the Whitewater RAWS around 1800 PST on the 17th and continued through 0800 PST on the 18th. The peak gust of 63 mph occurred around 2200 PST on the 17th.||Winds first gusted over 45 mph at the Edom Hill mesonet around 1800 PST on the 17th and continued through 0900 PST on the 18th. The peak gust of 55 mph occurred around 0800 PST on the 18th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching upper-level low pressure system resulted in strong, gusty westerly/northwesterly winds in the mountains and through the passes and canyons. Typical with these events, the strongest winds were through the Banning Pass and nearby canyons.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds first gusted over 45 mph at the Sky Valley mesonet station around 0930 PST on the 23rd and continued through around 2200 PST that day. The peak gust of 62+ mph occurred around 1800 PST. Winds again gusted over 50 mph from 0530 through 1800 PST on the 25th. During this time, several gusts over 65 mph were recorded including a peak gust of 75 mph around 0200 PST on the 25th. ||Winds first gusted over 45 mph at the Whitewater RAWS around 1800 PST on the 22nd and continued through the 24th. Several gusts 45-55 mph were recorded including a few gusts to 60 mph. Winds again gusted over 50 mph from 2300 on the 24th through 1200 PST on the 25th. During this time, several gusts over 50 mph were recorded including a peak gust of 62 mph around 1000 PST on the 25th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure aloft began building south along the west coast on the 23rd, deepening into a strong closed low over central California on the 26th. This low resulted in a deeper marine layer, scattered showers along and west of the mountains, below normal temperatures and strong, gusty winds in the mountains and deserts, as well as nearby canyons and passes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Sky Valley mesonet station between 1530 PST on the 4th and 0430 PST on the 5th. During this time, several gusts over 60 mph were measured including a peak gust of 74 mph around 1600 PST on the 4th. There were two periods of high winds, one from 1530 to 1900 PST on the 4th and the other from 0200-0430 PST on the 5th.||Peak wind gusts of 57 and 59 mph were also measured at the Edom Hill mesonet and the Whitewater RAWS, respectively, during this period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system moving through the west has brought strong, gusty southwest to west winds to the mountains and deserts. Most affected locations had winds 20-30 with gusts to 50 mph, with the windiest canyon locations seeing gusts over 65 mph. No damage was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Sky Valley mesonet between 1900 PST on the 8th and 2200 PST on the 9th. During this time, several gusts over 60 mph were recorded including a peak gust of 65 mph measured around 1900 PST on the 9th. ||During this time, the Edom Hill mesonet also recorded a peak gust of 58 mph around 2100 PST on the 9th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level trough moving by to the north of the CWA resulted in gusty westerly winds in the mountains and deserts on the 8th and 9th. The wind-prone canyons and desert slope locations were again the ones with the highest wind gusts.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Highland fire started around 1220 PST on the 16th, near the intersection of Potrero Road and Wolfskill Extension Truck Trail, near Beaumont. No structures or homes were threatened or evacuated. No injuries were reported. The fire burned a total of 2,171  acres before being fully contained at 1700 PST on the 18th. The cause of the fire is unknown and under investigation.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The View fire started around 2015 PST on the 17th, at the intersection of Desert View and Cottonwood Roads, near the city of Cabazon. No structures or homes were damaged or destroyed. No injuries were reported. Fifteen families within the community were evacuated, but no evacuation shelter was needed. The fire burned a total of 376 acres before being fully contained at 1700 PST on the 18th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds first gusted over 58 mph at the Whitewater RAWS between 1250 and 0150 PST on the 19th and stayed elevated through around 1700 PST the same day. During that time several gusts over 60 mph were measured, including a peak gust of 69 mph recorded between 0450 and 0550 PST on the 19th. ||A peak wind gust of 59 mph was also recorded at the Edom Hill mesonet station on this day around 0400 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system moved eastward through the Great Basin, bringing strong onshore flow and gusty west to northwest winds for the mountains and deserts during the overnight and early morning. Winds were mostly localized to the favored mountain passes and desert slopes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorms developed across much of eastern Riverside county during the morning hours on July 31st. The airmass was very moist and unstable, and the presence of a weather disturbance led to very heavy rainfall. The excessive rain led to episodes of flash flooding, including the area around Desert Center, and a Flash Flood Warning was issued at 1015 am. According to a trained weather spotter in Desert Center, at 1027 am, flash flooding caused Kaiser Road to be underwater, with flood waters threatening Interstate 10 in the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across eastern Riverside county during the morning hours on July 31st. The atmosphere was very moist and unstable, and the presence of a weather disturbance in the area allowed the storms to produce locally heavy rainfall with rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The excessive rains led to episodes of flash flooding, affecting communities such as Desert Center, Mecca and Eagle Mountain. The primary impact of the flash flooding involved road closures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorms developed across much of eastern Riverside county during the morning hours on July 31st. The airmass was very moist and unstable, and the presence of a weather disturbance resulted in excessive rainfall with rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The heavy rain led to the issuance of a Flash Flood Warning at 1015 am. According to California Department of Highways, or Cal Trans, at 1230 pm highway 177 was closed due to flooding, in the area about 13 miles northeast of Desert Center.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across eastern Riverside county during the morning hours on July 31st. The atmosphere was very moist and unstable, and the presence of a weather disturbance in the area allowed the storms to produce locally heavy rainfall with rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The excessive rains led to episodes of flash flooding, affecting communities such as Desert Center, Mecca and Eagle Mountain. The primary impact of the flash flooding involved road closures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorms developed across much of eastern Riverside county during the morning hours on July 31st. The airmass was very moist and unstable, and the presence of a weather disturbance led to excessive rainfall with rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The heavy rain led to episodes of flash flooding, and a Flash Flood Warning was issued for most of eastern Riverside county at 1015 am. According to the California Department of Highways, or Cal Trans, at 1230 pm flash flooding was observed in Box Canyon, and Box Canyon road was closed.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across eastern Riverside county during the morning hours on July 31st. The atmosphere was very moist and unstable, and the presence of a weather disturbance in the area allowed the storms to produce locally heavy rainfall with rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The excessive rains led to episodes of flash flooding, affecting communities such as Desert Center, Mecca and Eagle Mountain. The primary impact of the flash flooding involved road closures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dillon Road and Fargo Canyon Road flooded due to heavy rain from a thunderstorm.||A local newspaper reported a wall of water flowing through a Thousand Palms Neighborhood causing minor flooding to several homes. ||Several roads were closed due to flooding in the Coachella Valley including: Box Canyon Road from mecca to Interstate 10, Highway 177 from Interstate 10 to Highway 62, and Highway 62 from Vidal Junction to Highway 177.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large moisture surge moved over the area as monsoon flow rotated around the western edge of an upper high over the southern plains and into southern California. Daytime heating, along with a low to mid-level circulation coming up from the south, was sufficient to create the instability needed for thunderstorms over the mountains and deserts during the two-day period of the 30th and 31st. Heavy rain was the main threat from these storms and resulted in several instances of flash flooding, most notably in the San Diego County deserts and the Coachella Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Intense thunderstorms developed across much of eastern Riverside county during the morning hours on July 31st. The airmass was very moist and unstable, and the presence of a weather disturance led to excessive rainfall with rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The heavy rain led to episodes of flash flooding over northern portions of the county, and a Flash Flood Warning was issued at 1015 am. According to the California Department of Highways, or Cal Trans, flash flooding caused the road from Twenty Nine Palms eastwward to US Highway 95 to be flooded. The road, highway 62, was closed along the entire length, according to Cal Trans.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across eastern Riverside county during the morning hours on July 31st. The atmosphere was very moist and unstable, and the presence of a weather disturbance in the area allowed the storms to produce locally heavy rainfall with rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. The excessive rains led to episodes of flash flooding, affecting communities such as Desert Center, Mecca and Eagle Mountain. The primary impact of the flash flooding involved road closures.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Volcano fire started around 1045 PST on the 1st, near the intersection of Tenaja Road and Via Volcano, in La Cresta (near Murrieta). Voluntary evacuations were in place for residents in the area at a local high school. One unidentified structure was destroyed. Three firefighters received minor injuries; one was transported by paramedics for treatment. The fire burned a total of 350 acres before being fully contained around 0700 PST on the 2nd. The cause of the fire was determined to be motorized equipment used to clear brush.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Temescal RAWS near Lake Elsinore measured a wind gust of 88 mph between 1432 and 1532 PST, associated with a nearby warned thunderstorm. ||Winds were estimated at 60-65 mph from a microburst around 20 yards wide that caused damage in a residential neighborhood in northeast Temecula. It descended in a backyard and blew down the fences on the north and south ends of the yard. The fences were blown outward from the yard, indicative of a downward and outward thrust of winds.||Several large branches were broken and a few small trees downed in Trilogy at the Glen Ivy Resort and Spa. Estimated winds from the damage was 60 mph as determined by an NWS employee.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: These days were a continuation of the deep monsoonal flow that persisted over the area through much of the month. Thunderstorms developed each afternoon over the mountains, deserts and northern inland valleys, and quickly diminished by sunset with areas of rural, urban and flash flooding. Flooding activity on the 11th was focused around Big Bear and Victorville in San Bernardino County, as well as Campo in San Diego County. Thunderstorm activity also developed along the Elsinore Convergence Zone in eastern Riverside County. Thunderstorms in this area became severe and produced a couple damaging microbursts along with the small hail and heavy rain. Similar storms in the Elsinore area on the 12th produced a landspout and another damaging microburst. Significant flooding was also observed in the Forest Falls area on that day. Mostly minor urban flooding was observed in the upper deserts and Forest Falls again on the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A land spout tornado was associated with and southwest of the parent (non-supercell) thunderstorm that was over Nuevo, on the east side of Perris. The land spout appeared to be over the fields just east of or near Interstate 215. Separate wind damage from the parent thunderstorm was observed to the northeast over Nuevo on Menifee Road. |There was no apparent damage from the land spout itself. A spotter also sent in video of the land spout.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: These days were a continuation of the deep monsoonal flow that persisted over the area through much of the month. Thunderstorms developed each afternoon over the mountains, deserts and northern inland valleys, and quickly diminished by sunset with areas of rural, urban and flash flooding. Flooding activity on the 11th was focused around Big Bear and Victorville in San Bernardino County, as well as Campo in San Diego County. Thunderstorm activity also developed along the Elsinore Convergence Zone in eastern Riverside County. Thunderstorms in this area became severe and produced a couple damaging microbursts along with the small hail and heavy rain. Similar storms in the Elsinore area on the 12th produced a landspout and another damaging microburst. Significant flooding was also observed in the Forest Falls area on that day. Mostly minor urban flooding was observed in the upper deserts and Forest Falls again on the 13th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm caused significant straight-line wind damage from a wet microburst on the east side of Perris on Nuevo Road near Menifee Road. Several power poles were snapped completely and fell over like dominoes. Several vehicles were trapped in between the downed poles, though no one was injured. Law enforcement was called in to close off several roads in the area. The wind also tore up some roofing on a few homes in the area. This damage was likely caused by winds from a microburst and not the nearby landspout, though both were the result of the same parent thunderstorm cell.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: These days were a continuation of the deep monsoonal flow that persisted over the area through much of the month. EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the west side of Perris, on Olive and Ellis Streets and just north of Highway 74, several small and large tree limbs down. Two power poles were broken by wind but remained leaning on Ellis Street just north of Highway 74. One rural street in that area was closed due to water about 12 inches deep. Estimated wind gusts were 50-55 mph for just this area. This damage was determined to be associated with a wet microburst from the severe storm in the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was observed just south of Perris from approximately 1525 to 1535 PST on the 12th. The funnel was observed by a spotter located near Albert Hill, north of Lake Elsinore as the severe thunderstorm moved east along Highway 74. The funnel was not determined to be associated with the landspout east of Perris.
