The Buck fire started around 1156 PST on the 14th due to lightning, along Sage Road between Lewis Valley Road and Buck Road near the town of Sage in Riverside County. Voluntary evacuations were in place. Four residences were destroyed. Five firefighters received minor injuries and one civilian received burn injuries. The fire burned a total of 2681 acres before being fully controlled around 0700 PST on the 20th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rob Balfour reported strong winds at the Buck Fire base camp at Diamond Lake, with estimated max gusts of 60 mph. The winds destroyed two large tents, several camping tents and some awnings. A few port-a-potties overturned as well.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep, monsoonal flow continued from earlier in the month. Some minor flooding occurred near Dulzura in San Diego County. Flash flooding occurred in Apple Valley and Victorville (one high water rescue, damage to property and school and multiple road closures), mud and debris on roadways in Alpine, and more flash flooding in Mill Creek at Forest Falls. The Victorville area was hardest hit during these two days.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Vista fire started around 1052 PST on the 20th, along Vista Road at Rawson Road in Winchester in Riverside County. No evacuations were needed and no structures were threatened or destroyed. Two firefighters received minor injuries. The fire burned a total of 500 acres before being fully controlled around 1900 PST on the 20th (same day). The cause of the fire was determined to be a flare used to kill small animals, called a Gopher Gasser.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Major flash flooding in Cathedral City with 1 to 2 feet of rapidly moving water, closing several roads including East Palm Canyon (Highway 111) and Araby Drive. Water forced mud and debris into several businesses in town, causing significant damage.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The month ended with one last major monsoon day. Convection developed rapidly and near the same time as an approaching short wave trough and daytime heating. Flash flooding was reported in many locations with several road closures in the Inland Empire, Victorville, Chihuahua Valley and the Coachella Valley (Cathedral City). Extensive damage was done by flood waters in Moreno Valley, Victorville and Cathedral City with a few high water rescues and residences and businesses inundated with mud and debris.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The March AFB ASOS recorded a peak gust of 61 mph at 1347 PST. One of the planes at the museum was turned 180 degrees by the severe winds.||An Atmospheric Science teacher at nearby UC Riverside estimated wind gusts to 60 mph from a passing thunderstorm going through campus around the same time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The month ended with one last major monsoon day. Convection developed rapidly and near the same time as an approaching short wave trough and daytime heating. Flash flooding was reported in many locations with several road closures in the Inland Empire, Victorville, Chihuahua Valley and the Coachella Valley (Cathedral City). Extensive damage was done by flood waters in Moreno Valley, Victorville and Cathedral City with a few high water rescues and residences and businesses inundated with mud and debris.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding which closed San Timoteo Canyon Road. Six vehicles were stuck in the water. One person was rescued from a vehicle surrounded by a mud flow on San Timoteo Canyon Road and Live Oak Canyon Road. Rainfall of 1.53 inches fell in one hour at March AFB in Riverside. |Eastbound Highway 60 was closed at Redlands Boulevard due to flooding as well. |Mud and water also inundated a few homes in the Moreno Valley area.|At least 1 swift water rescue needed to be performed, including the one at Oliver Street and Cactus Avenue in Moreno Valley. Firefighters had to rescue persons trapped in their vehicle with water reported up to the windows.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter RIV230 reported heavy rain and lightning. Lightning struck a nearby palm tree, which then burst into flames. Winds also gusted to 25 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported street flooding with water up to the curbs in some places at the north end of Lake Elsinore near Albert Hill.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong and very slow moving thunderstorm developed to the north of Desert Center during the late afternoon hours on September 3rd. Radar indicated that up to 2 inches fell along Desert Center Rice Road, or State Route 177, north of Desert Center and the  heavy rain led to flash flooding. At 436 pm, the California Highway Patrol reported flooding along Highway 177 approximately 5 miles northeast of Desert Center. The flooding resulted in the closure of Desert Center Rice Road. At 423 pm, a Flash Flood Warning was issued for central Riverside county, including the area north of Desert Center, and it ran through 615 pm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and slow moving thunderstorm developed over central Riverside county during the late afternoon hours on September 3rd. The storm, which developed to the northeast of Desert Center, produced locally heavy rainfall with peak rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour. Flash flooding was observed along Highway 177 northeast of Desert Center, and prompted the issuance of a Flash Flood Warning.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Canyon fire started around 1052 PST on the 6th as three separate fires, near the intersection of Lambs Canyon Road and Gilman Springs Road near Beaumont in Riverside County. One firefighter received minor fire-related injuries and was transported by paramedics for treatment. The fire burned a total of 3 acres before being fully contained around 1150 PST the same day. The cause of the fire is unknown. CHP closed the #2 lane on northbound Highway 79 for a time.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A land spout was observed at 1330 PST along interstate 215 and highway 74 in Perris. No funnel was observed at the cloud base, and the land spout remained nearly stationary. Pictures and a video were submitted by spotters.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoonal moisture in easterly flow aloft brought showers and thunderstorms to the mountains and deserts each afternoon and evening. The activity on the 9th was mainly in the upper deserts, San Bernardino Mountains and the Inland Empire near Lake Elsinore. Flooding was reported along Highway 74 in Lake Elsinore with 3 to 5 inches of water covering the roadway, along with several downed trees, and a land spout in the nearby city of Perris. Outflow boundaries from storms created strong winds which picked up dust and lowered visibility in the Coachella Valley and near Borrego Springs. Visibility was also lowered to near zero at times with wind gusts around 60 MPH reported in the areas. Storms were more widespread on the 10th as a trough of low pressure drifted north from Mexico. Thunderstorms occurred over most mountain and desert locations, as well as the Inland Empire. Flash flooding was reported in Forest Falls and along Highway 76 in northern San Diego County. Highway 76 was closed for about an hour in the afternoon due to 12 to 18 inches of mud and debris in the road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee reported 3 to 5 inches of water flowing across the intersection of highway 74 and Lincoln in Lake Elsinore.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts at the Thermal ASOS gusted over 45 mph between 1916 and 1944 PST with a peak gust of 61 mph at 1928 PST. The ASOS reported visibility between three-quarters of a mile and 3 miles in blowing dust during that time frame.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds and low visibility in blowing dust forced several vehicles to pull over on Highway 86 in Mecca. The Department of Highways reported visibility of three-quarters of a mile at 1925 PST near Mecca. The ASOS reported visibility between three-quarters of a mile and 3 miles during that time frame. The Palm Springs ASOS also reported visibility between one-quarter and one-half mile with winds gusting to 47 mph between 1948 and 2053 PST. A spotter in Cathedral City also reported visibility down to one-eighth of a mile in blowing dust with wind gusts to 36 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ALERT rain gauge at Kent Sea Farms recorded 5.51 inches of rain in 24 hours, 4.18 inches of which was in the past 12 hours. The vast majority of the rain fell between 0000 and 0700 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure area moving slowly northeast over the lower deserts, and an associated weak disturbance aloft triggered a slow moving thunderstorm in the lower Coachella Valley near the community of Mecca just after midnight PST. With abundant moisture extending from the surface to 400 mb, and precipitable water values between 1.8 and over 2.2 inches, this storm remained nearly stationary from approximately 0200 through 0800 PST and produced between 3 and 5.5 inches of rainfall near Mecca (approximately 30 miles southeast of Palm Springs, CA). In addition, radar estimates were between 5 and 8 inches. Most of the rain fell between 0200 and 0400 PST, which resulted in a rare and damaging flash flooding in this area. This was eventually found to be a 1000-year flood event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in flooding along 66th Avenue east of Johnson Avenue. County Road Department was dispatched to barricade the roads. |A short distance upstream, the Thermal airport measured 1.42 inches of rain between 0019 and 0316 PST, over an inch of which fell between 0019 and 0236 PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in flooding along State Highway 111, just east of the intersection with Colfax Street. The roadway there was covered with 3 feet of water. |A mesonet station, at Kent Sea Farms, just west of this location recorded 3.38 inches of rain between 0050 and 0419 PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A stationary thunderstorm brought persistent heavy rain in Mecca between 0200 and 0800 PST, resulting in flash flooding of two mobile home parks. Approximately 15 to 20 mobile homes in the Duroville and Saint Anthony's mobile home parks were damaged. The American Red Cross set up an evacuation center at the Mecca Family and Farm Workers Services Facility for the approximately 1500 residents affected. A boil water message was issued for these locations as well. Saul Martinez Elementary School also reported water damage to 15 classrooms, the teachers' lounge and the administration building with 2 to 3 inches of water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire department and rescue officials in Riverside County reported residential flooding of approximately 4 homes on the 91000 block of 5th Street in Mecca due to heavy downpours. No injuries reported and depth of flood waters was unknown.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets were flooded due to heavy rain, stranding motorists in their vehicles. Streets affected included Wineville Avenue, Limonite Avenue, 50th Street, Ben Nevis Blvc, Quartz Canyon Road, Fircrest Lane, Agate Street, Mission Blvd, Hastings Blvd, Fleming Street, Glen Street and Villa Woods Drive in Jurupa Valley. No one was injured.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper-level low pressure system dug south along the West Coast, moving inland directly over southern California. A vorticity maximum rotating around the low, along with the setup of a California Bight Coastal Convergence Zone (between drainage winds off the land and onshore flow from the low) created the perfect conditions for showers, thunderstorms and funnel clouds. The cold air instability and warm waters resulted in waterspouts and ocean-effect instability showers over the coastal waters and locally onshore during the morning hours. Showers and thunderstorms formed inland from afternoon heating as the low moved onshore, resulting in urban flooding in areas of the Inland Empire. The heaviest amounts ranged from three quarters of an inch to one inch, with other nearby areas receiving one-tenth of an inch to a half of an inch. Impacts included numerous street closures and 10 homes with either external or internal water damage in the Riverside, Colton and Fontana areas. Highway 52 at Interstate 15 in San Diego County was also closed for an hour due to flooding and multiple accidents.|Cold-air instability continued on the 12th, producing several more waterspouts off the Orange County coast.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two homes on Crestview Drive between Mount Shasta and Mount Rushmore Drives sustained damage to the insides of the residences. Eight additional homes on the block sustained damage on the external portion. No injuries and no residents displaced.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Highland Springs RAWS between 0116 and 0216 PST and ended between 0716 and 0816 PST on the 26th. During that time, winds were sustained 38 to 43 mph and gusting above 58 mph. The peak gust of 64 mph was measured between 0216 and 0316 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure over the Great Basin brought strong and gusty northeast winds through and below the passes and canyons. The San Diego mountain areas recorded several gusts over 45 mph. The same occurred below the Banning Pass in the Inland Empire and the canyons in and below the Santa Ana Mountains. Three stations, however did reach high wind criteria. No damage was reported with these gusts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Whitewater RAWS between 1150 and 1250 PST on the 8th and ended between 0650 and 0750 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained 35-48 mph with gusts over 59-80 mph. The peak gust of 80 mph was recorded between 0450 and 0550 PST.||The Sky Valley mesonet station reported sustained winds of 44 mph with gusts to 66 mph between 0443 and 0553 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold low pressure system from the Gulf of Alaska moved through California, bringing light to moderate precipitation. A few locations in the San Diego County and San Bernardino County Mountains received between 1 and 2 inches of rain. One of these locations experienced a debris flow along State Route 18, in the upper Waterman Canyon just south of Crestline, where boulders the size of beer kegs washed across both lanes of the highway. Strong and gusty west to northwest winds accompanied this system, with several mountain and desert slope stations reporting sustained winds over 45 mph and gusts to 80 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet station between 0543 and 0643 PST on the 9th and ended between 0943 and 1043 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained 32-56 mph with gusts 56-79 mph. The peak gust of 79 mph was recorded between 0743 and 0843 PST. Another gust to 61 mph was measured later in the afternoon between 1443 and 1543 PST.||High winds began at the Whitewater RAWS between 0450 and 0550 PST on the 9th and ended between 1050 and 1150 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained 31-41 mph with gusts over 58-61 mph. The peak gust of 61 mph was recorded between 0650 and 0750 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold low pressure system from the Gulf of Alaska moved through California, bringing light to moderate precipitation. A few locations in the San Diego County and San Bernardino County Mountains received between 1 and 2 inches of rain. One of these locations experienced a debris flow along State Route 18, in the upper Waterman Canyon just south of Crestline, where boulders the size of beer kegs washed across both lanes of the highway. Strong and gusty west to northwest winds accompanied this system, with several mountain and desert slope stations reporting sustained winds over 45 mph and gusts to 80 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak gust of 64 mph was measured at the Sky Valley mesonet station around 1300 PST on the 24th. Winds were gusting over 50 mph between 0943 and 1342 PST.|High winds began at the Whitewater RAWS between 0250 and 0350 PST and ended between 0950 and 1050 PST on the 24th. Winds dropped below high wind for a time during this period, but a peak gust of 60 mph was measured between 0850 and 0950 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough moved through southern California late on the 23rd into the morning of the 24th, providing another round of light to moderate precipitation, and strong winds in the mountains and desert slopes. Many locations gusted over 50 mph during the morning and early afternoon of the 24th. Another, deeper, trough dug south through the region and on the 26th into the morning of the 27th, bringing more strong, gusty winds to the mountains and desert slopes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted over 50 mph between 1200 and 1900 PST on the 26th. During this time, peak wind gusts of 59 mph and 64 mph occurred around 1700 and 1800 PST, respectively.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak trough moved through southern California late on the 23rd into the morning of the 24th, providing another round of light to moderate precipitation, and strong winds in the mountains and desert slopes. Many locations gusted over 50 mph during the morning and early afternoon of the 24th. Another, deeper, trough dug south through the region and on the 26th into the morning of the 27th, bringing more strong, gusty winds to the mountains and desert slopes.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A traffic collision involving 4 vehicles occurred on Interstate 15 near the Lake Street exit, north of Lake Elsinore on the 31st. CHP reported dense fog at the time of the accident. Two vehicles were involved in the initial accident and were blocking the #1 lane. Two additional vehicles struck these vehicles.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold, upper-level trough dug south along the West Coast and closed off, before moving inland and stalling over southern California for the 29th and 30th. This system resulted in more precipitation, as well as scattered thunderstorms and a few waterspouts, including one off the coast of Oceanside. Dense fog also formed during the early morning of the 31st, resulting in a large accident involving 4 vehicles.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Highland Springs RAWS between 2000 PST on the 1st and 0200 PST on the 2nd. During this time, a peak gust of 64 mph was recorded between 2316 and 0016 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact upper-level low dropped south along the California coast, before moving inland over northern Baja, Mexico on the 1st and 2nd. Because of the limited moisture and inland trajectory, no precipitation was observed. However, there were strong, gusty west winds in the mountains and deserts those days.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sky Valley mesonet station recorded a peak gust of 76 mph around 1542 PST. During this afternoon, the  Thermal Airport ASOS measured a peak gust of 49 mph between 1251 and 1351 PST, with one-quarter mile visibility due to blowing dust.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold trough of low pressure dropped down the West Coast, before closing off over southern California. This system brought light to locally moderate showers to most areas, except the Coachella Valley, on the afternoon and evening of the 6th. Light showers lingered into the morning of the 7th near the mountains. Rainfall totals for the coast and valleys were mostly light, generally ranging from one-tenth to one-third of an inch, with three-quarters of an inch to an inch for the lower mountains and foothills. The lower deserts generally received less than one-tenth of an inch, with the exception of Borrego Springs with 0.16 inches of rain. The snow level fell to between 3500 and 4000 feet, with 1 to 3 inches of snow below 6000 feet, and up to 6 inches above 6000 feet.On the 10th, a very cold trough of low pressure from the northwest moved through southern California, bringing significant cooling, low snow levels, gusty west winds and light to locally moderate precipitation along and west of the mountains. The snow level dropped to around 2500 feet, with accumulating snow of around one-half inch down to around 3000 feet in locations such as Hesperia and the Cajon Pass in San Bernardino County, and Julian in San Diego County. Up to 5 inches of snow fell above 4000 feet. Chains were required in most mountain areas as well. Gusty winds also accompanied the storm on the 10th, even resulting in some blowing dust in the Coachella Valley. Strong winds across the coastal waters, combined with a large swell and astronomical high tides, resulted in minor coastal flooding during the morning of the 11th in La Jolla, Imperial Beach and Newport Beach. Most flooding was limited to a few beach parking lots and some nearby surface streets.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust of 65 mph occurred at the Sky Valley mesonet between 0044 and 0142 PST on the 14th and a peak gust of 65 mph between 0830 and 0845 PST. Sustained winds of 42 mph also occurred there around 0242 PST and 43 mph around 0843 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the 14th, the trough slowly began shifting eastward, allowing dry and warmer offshore flow to develop and providing gusty, northerly high winds through the passes and canyons, filtering down into the Inland Empire, causing some damage in the form of downed power lines and road signs. There were several stations reporting sustained winds of 40 mph or greater and gusts over 60 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0251 and 0351 PST on the 14th and ended between 0551 and 0651 PST the same morning. During this time, sustained winds were 45 to 48 mph with gusts over 60 mph, including the peak gust of 71 mph measured between 0351 and 0451 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the 14th, the trough slowly began shifting eastward, allowing dry and warmer offshore flow to develop and providing gusty, northerly high winds through the passes and canyons, filtering down into the Inland Empire, causing some damage in the form of downed power lines and road signs. There were several stations reporting sustained winds of 40 mph or greater and gusts over 60 mph.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported phone lines blown down in the vicinity of Highway 91 and West 14th Street. A large highway traffic sign and posts were also blown down along Highway 91 eastbound, just west of Arlington Avenue. Both of these reports were between 0400 and 0500 PST on the 14th. Later in the morning, around 0750 PST, another freeway sign was blown down near the Interstate 215 northbound off ramp at Baseline Street. Around 0930 PST that morning, a big rig trailer overturned on Interstate 15 southbound, near the Interstate 10 east connector.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the 14th, the trough slowly began shifting eastward, allowing dry and warmer offshore flow to develop and providing gusty, northerly high winds through the passes and canyons, filtering down into the Inland Empire, causing some damage in the form of downed power lines and road signs. There were several stations reporting sustained winds of 40 mph or greater and gusts over 60 mph.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: March Air Base in Riverside reported visibility of one-quarter mile or less from 0222 to 0957 PST on the 7th. The lowest visibility reached was one-sixteenth of a mile and occurred from 0658 to 0957 PST.||Riverside ASOS reported visibility of one-quarter mile from 0701 to 0837 PST in dense fog on the 7th. Ontario ASOS also reported one-quarter mile visibility for 15 minutes from 0732 to 0747 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold trough of low pressure from the northwest moved through southern California on the 7th through the 10th, bringing significant cooling, low snow levels, gusty west winds and light to locally moderate precipitation along and west of the mountains. A few embedded thunderstorms were also observed on the 8th, producing periods of pea-sized hail and graupel. Hail accumulation was blamed for multiple accidents, closing portion of Interstate 15 near El Cajon. Rainfall totals for the coast and valleys were mostly light, generally ranging from one-tenth to one-third of an inch, with three-quarters of an inch to an inch for the lower mountains and foothills. The lower deserts generally received less than one-tenth of an inch, with the exception of Borrego Springs with 0.16 inches of rain. The snow level dropped to 1500-2000 feet, with accumulating snow of 1-3 inches down to around 2600 feet in locations such as Beaumont and Yucaipa in the Inland Empire and Banning Pass. Significant snow fell above 5000 feet, with many locations receiving 6-12 inches. Some higher locations in the San Bernardino County mountains, such as Big Bear and Onyx Summit received up to 22 inches. During this storm, a major manhunt was underway for an ex-LAPD officer who was on the run after a killing spree. All major national news outlets were covering the search. A weak trough moved southward, early on the 10th, and interacted with residual low level moisture to produce a few light showers, mainly in the mountains and inland valleys of San Diego County. These showers only amounted to a tenth of an inch or less.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sky Valley Mesonet station recorded a peak gust of 71 mph around 1400 PST on the 8th. Occasional wind gusts of 58 mph or higher were recorded between 0300 and 1500 PST that day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A big rig overturned on Highway 111 at Overture Drive, near Windy Point. Northbound lanes were closed for more than two hours for a fuel spill cleanup. A highway department wind gauge 2.2 miles northwest of the accident measured gusts of 38-50 mph around the time of the incident. The truck was reportedly empty.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong, cold low pressure system dropped down the West Coast from the Gulf of Alaska and directly over southern California. This storm was accompanied by isolated thunderstorms with small hail, moderate rain showers west of the mountains, winter storm conditions in the mountains, and very strong wind gusts along and below the ridges and desert slopes. Most coast and valley locations received between one-quarter and three-quarters of an inch of rain, while some foothill locations received between 1.0 and 1.5 inches of rain. The very cold conditions led to significantly low snow levels down to 2000 feet, with accumulations as low as 2300 feet (Shelter Valley ��� San Diego County). Most locations above 4000 feet received 6 to 13 inches of snow with widespread chain control everywhere. The high desert received up to 3 inches of snow as well, down to 2900 feet, closing several schools and requiring CHP escorts on Interstate 15. The snow also resulted in numerous accidents, especially along Interstate 15, where the northbound lanes in the high desert were closed for a time due to the sheer number of incidents. Snow and accidents also temporarily closed Interstate 8 near the Crestwood Pass on the morning of the 20th. Mountain and foothill locations received an additional 1 to 3 inches of snow from the morning showers. A second, smaller disturbance behind this low brought some light showers to San Diego County on the afternoon of the 21st. Amounts ranged from a few hundredths to two-tenths of an inch, mostly in the valleys and foothills.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0151 and 0251 PST on the 24th and ended around 1400 PST the same day. During this time several gusts over 60 mph were recorded, including the peak gust of 66 mph measured between 0751 and 0851 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure over the Great Basin brought gusty northeast winds through and below canyons and passes with the strongest winds during the early to mid morning on the 24th in the Santa Ana Mountains and foothills, the San Gorgonio Pass and San Diego County mountains.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a power line down at the intersection of Twenty-nine Palms Highway and North Indian Canyon Drive, just south of Morongo Valley.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure over the Great Basin brought gusty northeast winds through and below canyons and passes with the strongest winds during the early to mid morning on the 24th in the Santa Ana Mountains and foothills, the San Gorgonio Pass and San Diego County mountains.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wildfire (cause still under investigation) started at 1643 PST, February 28 in the Santa Ana River bottom, burning heavy fuels near the intersection of Rio Road and Calle Hermosa in Jurupa Valley. Voluntary evacuation were in effect on Greenbrier Drive and Grassy Trail in the city of Riverside. There were no injuries, but one structure and one outbuilding were damaged. Power lines were also reported down in the river bottom area. The fire burned 311 acres before being fully contained at 1800 PST on March 3rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet station between 1422 and 1522 PST on the 3rd, and ended between 2143 and 2243 PST the same day. During this period, a peak gust of 67 mph was measured between 1400 and 1500 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure, which built over the Great Basin, created strong Santa Anna offshore winds on March 1st. Northeast to east winds gusted in the 60 mph range at the Sill Hill mesonet site. The high quickly broke down on March 2nd, then an approaching upper level low pressure trough created gusty west winds on March 3rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet between 0343 and 0443 PST on the 8th and ended between 1343 and 1443 the same day. During this time, two periods of high winds were observed with a brief lull between. During those high wind periods, peak gusts of 68 and 80 mph were observed, the latter being around 0600 PST. California Highway Patrol reported an overturned big rig along Interstate 10 near Date Palm Drive. There were no injuries, but the number 3 and 4 eastbound lanes were closed for about two hours for the investigation. The Palm Springs airport reported a loss of utility power during this time as well, attributing it to the high winds nearby. A power pole was also downed by winds near Whitewater Wash and Vista Chino in Palm Springs, along with several downed palm trees across the valley. Vista Chino road was closed for a time while crews fixed the pole.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep trough of low pressure from the northwest moved through southern California, bringing minor cooling, gusty, light to moderate precipitation along and west of the mountains and damaging west winds to the mountains and deserts. West winds were sustained 30-50 mph with gusts up to 80-90 mph. Damage to trees and structures, as well as blowing dust and sand, was reported in the Borrego Springs and Palm Springs areas. A big rig was also blown over along Interstate 10 in Palm Springs. Rainfall totals for the southwest and west slopes of the San Bernardino County mountains were also significant for this event. Amounts from one-quarter of an inch up to 1.5 inches were recorded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerful spring storm brought windy conditions to much of eastern Riverside county during the day on April 8th. Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph were common, and led to the issuance of a Wind Advisory which ran from 10 am PDT to 8 pm PDT. According to an on-line article posted on the KESQ.COM website, at 205 pm a dust devil struck the Salton City RV Resort in Salton City California. The dust devil combined with the already strong and gusty winds to produce damage at the RV park. Awnings were down, some siding was ripped off and a water pipe was broken. No injuries were reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level Pacific low pressure system brought strong, gusty and damaging winds to portions of southeast California on April 8th, especially the lower deserts of Imperial county. Gusty southwest to west winds developed during the morning hours, and continued into the early evening, prompting issuance of numerous products, including Wind Advisories, Blowing Dust Advisories, and High Wind Warnings. Peak gusts in excess of 60 mph were seen at times, strong enough to damage area trees and weaker structures such as sheds. The strong gradient winds were not associated with thunderstorms.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet in Anza recorded a 1 minute gust to 58 mph at 1320 PST on the 9th, corresponding to a reported strong dust devil that tracked through a mobile home park in Jurupa Valley, near Riverside, damaging carports, several metal awnings and roofs. At least 6 metal awnings were lifted high in the air, some weighing over 100 pounds. No injuries were reported despite the flying debris. Skies were clear at the time.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep trough of low pressure from the northwest moved through southern California, bringing minor cooling, gusty, light to moderate precipitation along and west of the mountains and damaging west winds to the mountains and deserts. West winds were sustained 30-50 mph with gusts up to 80-90 mph. Damage to trees and structures, as well as blowing dust and sand, was reported in the Borrego Springs and Palm Springs areas. A big rig was also blown over along Interstate 10 in Palm Springs. Rainfall totals for the southwest and west slopes of the San Bernardino County mountains were also significant for this event. Amounts from one-quarter of an inch up to 1.5 inches were recorded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very windy conditions existed along the Interstate 10 corridor in the Coachella Valley on the evening of the 14th, with blowing dust bringing visibility down to under one-eighth of a mile. KESQ news reported a sand storm impacting the Coachella Music Festival with winds gusting up to 40 mph at the Coachella mesonet. California Highway Patrol reported a large quantity of sand  in the roadway near Vamer Road and Monterey Avenue the following morning. The Desert Sun newspaper reported police closed Gene Autry Trail between Interstate 10 and Via Escuela and Indian Canyon Road from Palm Springs Train Road to Tramway Road due to blowing sand and reduced visibility of less than one-quarter mile. These major roads remained closed until the 16th due to blowing sand and downed trees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper-level low over the Pacific Northwest deepened and swung through the Great Basin the evening of the 14th through the 16th, driving strong and gusty westerly winds across the mountains and deserts. These winds resulted in widespread blowing dust in the Coachella Valley, with visibilities down to one-eights of a mile or less at times and accumulating sand, closing main roadways through the valley. Several mountain stations recorded sustained winds of 35-45 mph and gusts 60 to 80 mph. Following this event a weak upper low off the coast produced elevated thunderstorms in northwest San Diego County, with 60 total strikes and up to 1/2 size hail during the evening of April 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sky Valley Mesonet gusted over 58 mph off and on from around 0500 PST on the 14th to around 1000 PST on the 16th. The Whitewater RAWS also reported sustained winds 42-44 mph between 2150 PST on the 15th and 0150 PST on the 16th with gusts 58 to 68 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper-level low over the Pacific Northwest deepened and swung through the Great Basin the evening of the 14th through the 16th, driving strong and gusty westerly winds across the mountains and deserts. These winds resulted in widespread blowing dust in the Coachella Valley, with visibilities down to one-eights of a mile or less at times and accumulating sand, closing main roadways through the valley. Several mountain stations recorded sustained winds of 35-45 mph and gusts 60 to 80 mph. Following this event a weak upper low off the coast produced elevated thunderstorms in northwest San Diego County, with 60 total strikes and up to 1/2 size hail during the evening of April 24th.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Summit fire started near N. San Gorgonio Avenue and Summit Drive in Banning (Riverside County) around 1138 PST on the 1st. The brush fire burned rapidly toward the northwest, driven by Santa Ana winds of 30-40 mph, destroying one residence and one out building. The fire threatened 450 homes in and around Cherry Valley, CA. Mandatory evacuations were in place for approximately 750 people there. Two firefighters received unknown injuries. The fire burned a total of 3166 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on the 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0451 and 0551 PST on the 2nd and ended between 0951 and 1051 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained 30 to 45 mph with gusts mostly above 60 mph, including the peak gust of 70 mph measured between 0651 and 0751 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure built into the Great Basin, bringing strong and gusty northeast winds through and below passes and canyons during the morning of the 2nd. Winds temporarily decreased that night, before increasing again, somewhat, the morning of the 3rd.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds gusted 35-40 mph with gusts above 55 mph between 0500 and 1000 PST on the 2nd. During this time, a peak gust of 62 mph was measured between 0816 and 0916 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure built into the Great Basin, bringing strong and gusty northeast winds through and below passes and canyons during the morning of the 2nd. Winds temporarily decreased that night, before increasing again, somewhat, the morning of the 3rd.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Van Buren wildfire started around 0724 PST on the 2nd in the median of Van Buren Boulevard at Jurupa Road in Jurupa Valley (Riverside County). Jurupa Rd was closed from Van Buren to Rutile and Van Buren closed from Jurupa to Rutile. Evacuations were ordered for a few hours. The fire burned 12 acres, but destroyed two homes, an RV and 5 out buildings, with damage to two additional residences. No injuries were reported. The fire was fully contained around 1330 PST on the 2nd. The cause of the fire is likely a discarded cigarette.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palm Springs ASOS recorded a high temperature of 118 degrees, which tied the previous record set on the 28th in 1979. The Indio mesonet station also tied their old record at 118, set in 2003.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-setting ridge of high pressure (600 dm over northern New Mexico) built in over the Great Basin and desert Southwest, beginning around June 28th, lasting through approximately July 7, when it hit another peak in temperatures. This resulted in extreme high temperatures, especially in the Coachella Valley and San Diego County mountains, as well as well above normal across the region, as a whole, during this period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palm Springs and Thermal ASOS stations both recorded a high temperature of 122 degrees, which broke their old records of 121 and 118, respectively, in 1994. The Indio mesonet station set a record high of 121, breaking their old record of 117, set also in 1994.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-setting ridge of high pressure (600 dm over northern New Mexico) built in over the Great Basin and desert Southwest, beginning around June 28th, lasting through approximately July 7, when it hit another peak in temperatures. This resulted in extreme high temperatures, especially in the Coachella Valley and San Diego County mountains, as well as well above normal across the region, as a whole, during this period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cathedral Canyon RAWS reached a high of 115 degrees. The Indian Wells mesonet reached a high of 122 degrees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-setting ridge of high pressure (600 dm over northern New Mexico) built in over the Great Basin and desert Southwest, beginning around June 29th, lasting through approximately July 7, when it hit another peak in temperatures. This resulted in extreme high temperatures, well above normal across the region during this period. The hottest days in July were the 1st through the 3rd, during which several record high minimums were set, as well as highs well over 100 degrees. Prolonged heat in the higher terrain was a significant impact, like in San Diego County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palm Springs ASOS reached a high of 115 degrees. The Kent Sea Farms mesonet reached a high of 116 degrees. The Palm Desert mesonet reached a high of 116 degrees. The Mecca mesonet reached a high of 118 degrees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-setting ridge of high pressure (600 dm over northern New Mexico) built in over the Great Basin and desert Southwest, beginning around June 29th, lasting through approximately July 7, when it hit another peak in temperatures. This resulted in extreme high temperatures, well above normal across the region during this period. The hottest days in July were the 1st through the 3rd, during which several record high minimums were set, as well as highs well over 100 degrees. Prolonged heat in the higher terrain was a significant impact, like in San Diego County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pinyon RAWS reached a high of 103 degrees.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-setting ridge of high pressure (600 dm over northern New Mexico) built in over the Great Basin and desert Southwest, beginning around June 29th, lasting through approximately July 7, when it hit another peak in temperatures. This resulted in extreme high temperatures, well above normal across the region during this period. The Mountain Fire started around 1243 PST on July 15, near the junction of Highway 243 and Highway 74. It burned east of Mountain Center, through the Apple Canyon and Bonita Vista areas, and then along the Desert Divide and southern portion of the San Jacinto Wilderness. CAL FIRE Investigators have determined the cause of the Mountain Fire to be an electrical equipment failure on private property. Mandatory evacuations were ordered for the Idyllwild and Fern Valley areas, including the San Jacinto State Park Wilderness, Forest Service Wilderness and Forest Service campgrounds. Other evacuations include the Trails End Community at the top of Morris Ranch Road, the Andreas Canyon Club, south of Palm Canyon Drive in Palm Springs, Bonita Vista, Pine Springs and the Zen Mountain Center off Apple Canyon Road. Portions of Highways 74 and 243 were closed in this area. Several trails and campgrounds were closed as well. The Palm Springs Tram was shut down for the duration of the fire. The fire destroyed 3 mobile homes and 3 residences and damaged one other residence in Bonita Vista. In Pine Springs, 1 commercial building, a workshop, garage and cabin were destroyed. In addition, 11 other outbuildings and 4-6 vehicles were destroyed. Any possible injuries are unknown. The fire burned 27,531 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on July 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire Dispatch for the Mountain Fire reported 1 foot of water crossing Morris Ranch Road near the fire. Dispatch also reported a rockslide and debris flow across Highway 74.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system from the East brought a surge of subtropical monsoon moisture into the region. These ingredients set off periods of showers and thunderstorms, with areas of flash flooding affecting the San Diego, Riverside and San Bernardino County mountains, as well as the high desert on the 21st and 22nd, including significant rainfall and flash flooding the morning of the 21st, resulting from a nocturnal MCS. Rainfall amounts varied widely, though some of the stronger storms produced very heavy rain of 2-3 inches at a time. This heavy rain combined with recent burn areas on the 21st to produce major debris flows, most notably at the Mountain Fire in Riverside County, near Idyllwild. Several locations within this burn area reported rock and debris flows across roadways, including Highway 74. One debris flow even tore through a pond, displacing the water and killing the fish. Portions of the Sunrise Highway and Interstate 8 in the San Diego County mountains and roadways in Ocotillo Wells were closed due to large amounts of flowing water, mud and rocks. The bulk of the storms on the 22nd affected the San Bernardino County mountains, especially the Big Bear area, where three homes were flooded. Another area of Big Bear was blanketed with up to 1.5 inches of accumulated hail, ranging from one-quarter to one-half inch in size, shredding some plants and flowers. The Anza Borrego State Park, in the San Diego County deserts, experienced the worst flash flooding on the 22nd. Dual-Pol radar reported estimates of 2 to 4 inches of rainfall within portions of the park. Several locations along Highway 78, through the park, had water, mud and rocks flowing over the road, the deepest of which was 12 inches deep and about 30 feet across. No one could pass through, stranding one car between this flow and another about 6 inches deep. The Fish Creek drainage within the park also experienced flash flooding, carrying away and destroying 3 unoccupied vehicles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The stream gauge at Palm Canyon Creek reported a water rise of 1.5 feet in a normally dry creek bed around 315 PST. This gauge later measured a peak flow of 211 cfs at 1430 PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1129 PST, law enforcement reported 2 and a half feet of mud and water washing across Larsen Lane near the cross-section with Dillon road in Sky Valley. At 1350 PST, an 80-ft swath of dirt and rocks was in the roadway, The dirt was 3 feet thick with most rocks bigger than bowling balls. The road was closed due to it being impassable.

The Fish Creek drainage within the park also experienced flash flooding, carrying away and destroying 3 unoccupied vehicles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reports a hard closure of the intersection of Tyler Street and 64th Street in Mecca, due to roadway flooding. Intersection closed due to roads being impassable.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system from the East brought a surge of subtropical monsoon moisture into the region. These ingredients set off periods of showers and thunderstorms, with areas of flash flooding affecting the San Diego, Riverside and San Bernardino County mountains, as well as the high desert on the 21st and 22nd, including significant rainfall and flash flooding the morning of the 21st, resulting from a nocturnal MCS. Rainfall amounts varied widely, though some of the stronger storms produced very heavy rain of 2-3 inches at a time. This heavy rain combined with recent burn areas on the 21st to produce major debris flows, most notably at the Mountain Fire in Riverside County, near Idyllwild. Several locations within this burn area reported rock and debris flows across roadways, including Highway 74. One debris flow even tore through a pond, displacing the water and killing the fish. Portions of the Sunrise Highway and Interstate 8 in the San Diego County mountains and roadways in Ocotillo Wells were closed due to large amounts of flowing water, mud and rocks. The bulk of the storms on the 22nd affected the San Bernardino County mountains, especially the Big Bear area, where three homes were flooded. Another area of Big Bear was blanketed with up to 1.5 inches of accumulated hail, ranging from one-quarter to one-half inch in size, shredding some plants and flowers. The Anza Borrego State Park, in the San Diego County deserts, experienced the worst flash flooding on the 22nd. Dual-Pol radar reported estimates of 2 to 4 inches of rainfall within portions of the park. Several locations along Highway 78, through the park, had water, mud and rocks flowing over the road, the deepest of which was 12 inches deep and about 30 feet across. No one could pass through, stranding one car between this flow and another about 6 inches deep. The Fish Creek drainage within the park also experienced flash flooding, carrying away and destroying 3 unoccupied vehicles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Crews on the Mountain Fire reported 0.5 inches of rain in 30 minutes between 1258 and 1328 PST. A debris flow from the fire moved through a pond, displacing the water and killing the fish. Other crews reported 18 inches of water and mud across Apple Canyon Road near Highway 74.

These ingredients set off periods of showers and thunderstorms, with areas of flash flooding affecting the San Diego, Riverside and San Bernardino County mountains, as well as the high desert on the 21st and 22nd, including significant rainfall and flash flooding the morning of the 21st, resulting from a nocturnal MCS. Rainfall amounts varied widely, though some of the stronger storms produced very heavy rain of 2-3 inches at a time. This heavy rain combined with recent burn areas on the 21st to produce major debris flows, most notably at the Mountain Fire in Riverside County, near Idyllwild. Several locations within this burn area reported rock and debris flows across roadways, including Highway 74. One debris flow even tore through a pond, displacing the water and killing the fish. The Anza Borrego State Park, in the San Diego County deserts, experienced the worst flash flooding on the 22nd. Dual-Pol radar reported estimates of 2 to 4 inches of rainfall within portions of the park. Several locations along Highway 78, through the park, had water, mud and rocks flowing over the road, the deepest of which was 12 inches deep and about 30 feet across. No one could pass through, stranding one car between this flow and another about 6 inches deep. The Fish Creek drainage within the park also experienced flash flooding, carrying away and destroying 3 unoccupied vehicles.

The Falls Fire started around 0900 PST on the 5th, off of the Ortega Highway near Decker Canyon, in Riverside. The cause of the fire is still unknown. Due to the fire burning on the Trabuco Ranger District, the San Mateo Wilderness, El Cariso Campground, Blue Jay Campground, the Firefighter Memorial Picnic Area and Wildomar OHV area were closed. Road closures included the Ortega Hwy 74 from Lake Elsinore west to San Antonio Parkway. Intermittent road openings were allowed to residents only. Evacuations were ordered for Lakeland Village, Rancho Capistrano and Decker Canyon residents. Evacuation perimeter is between Grand/Ortega and Grand/Corydon. No structures were threatened and no injuries. Minor guardrail damage occurred as a result of a rock fall along the Ortega Highway. The fire burned 1416 acres before being fully contained around 1700 PST on the 9th.

The Silver Fire started due to lightning around 1305 PST on the 7th, along Poppet Flats Road near Hwy 243, south of Banning in Riverside County, with a critical rate of spread. Strong Banning pass breezes forced extreme growth according to fire personnel and smoke reduced visibility into Palm Springs on the first day. Mandatory evacuations for the communities of Poppet Flats, Twin Pines and Silent Valley. Evacuation warnings/voluntary were also issued for Diamond Zen Center, Pine Cove & Camp Azalea. Residents were instructed to evacuate through Hwy 243, south through Hwy 74 in Idyllwild to Hemet. Forty-seven people from the Twin Pines Ranch (Boys Youth Camp) were escorted down the mountain. The fire eventually split into two directions, moving into Poppet Flats, Silent Valley Club, Twin Pines and Cabazon, prompting mandatory evacuations to be expanded to the lower Cabazon area-Peach Street, Plum Street, Eucalyptus Street, and Riza Avenue, Ida Avenue, Helen Avenue East to Elm Street. Repeater sites, containing equipment for Department of Transportation, Department of Parks and Recreation, Cal Fire, CHP and Riverside County Fire, at Mt. Edna and Vista Grande were in the path of the fire. Black Mountain was evacuated and closed as a precaution. Boulder Basin and Black Mountain campgrounds on Black Mountain road were closed through august 15th.  Highway 243 was closed from 10.3 miles west to 1.5 miles west of Banning. 537 residences were threatened, 2 damaged and 26 destroyed, along with one commercial building and 21 outbuildings. Injuries to 12 firefighters and one civilian were reported. The fire burned 20,292 acres before being fully contained around 1840 PST on the 12th. This fire also had high media coverage, including national.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS stream gage at Palm Canyon Creek reported a 2.7 ft. rise between 1500 and 1600 PST, with an estimated flow of 363 cfs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon moisture from the southeast, as well as the remnants of Tropical Storm Ivo, set off thunderstorms along and east of a line from Big Bear, south to Tecate, Mexico each afternoon/evening. These storms produced very heavy rain, with over 2 inches measured at many mountain and desert locations including Agua Caliente, Borrego Springs, Pine Hills and La Quinta. Borrego Springs and the southern Coachella Valley were the hardest hit areas for flooding on the 23rd and 25th, with several roads closed due to heavy water flow and washouts with mud and debris. Several cars were nearly submerged in flooded roadways in La Quinta and Indio, stranding drivers. The Indio gauge along the Whitewater Storm Channel experienced a sharp rise from near zero to 1080 cfs over approximately 30 minutes on the afternoon of the 25th. Highway 62 near Desert Hot Springs was also affected with very a very wide and deep area of flowing water, rocks and debris. Highway S22 near Borrego Springs suffered significant road damage and road closures for up to 24 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Araby Road was closed at Palm Canyon Wash due to moving water and mud covering the roadway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture streaming north into Riverside county led to a very moist and unstable airmass. As a result, very strong thunderstorms developed across central Riverside county during the early afternoon hours on August 24th. Some of the storms affected the community of Eagle Mountain. A COOP observer located in Eagle Mountain reported that large hail, estimated to be one inch in diameter, fell for 30 minutes. No damage was reported due to the large hail.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Copious amounts of tropical moisture streamed northward into far southeastern California on August 24th, ahead of dissipating former tropical storm Ivo. The atmosphere over the lower California deserts became very moist and unstable, and scattered strong thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon hours. The storms generated copious amounts of rain, with rain rates in excess of 3 inches per hour. Flash flooding developed across portions of Imperial and eastern Riverside counties, especially in the area to the west of the Salton Sea. Some of the storms  produced gusty and damaging winds in excess of 60 mph, moderate hail and dense blowing dust. Numerous Flash Flood Warnings, Small Stream Flood Advisories, Severe Thunderstorm Warnings and Significant Weather Advisories were issued mainly during the afternoon hours for the deserts of southeast California.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture from dissipating former tropical storm Ivo spread north into eastern Riverside county on August 24th and it led to a very moist and unstable airmass. Strong thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon hours in the area around Desert Center and Eagle Mountain, and they produced copious rainfall with rain rates in excess of 3 inches per hour at times. The first Flash Flood Warning was issued for central Riverside county at 1227PST, and it was re-issued at 1417PST. Eventually the rains dissipated and the warning was allowed to expire at 1715PST. According to local law enforcement, at about 1530PST the heavy rain caused significant flash flooding of Highway 177 near mile marker 5, to the northeast of Desert Center. Numerous vehicles were turning around as the road was impassable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture streamed north into eastern Riverside county on August 24th, and it produced a very moist and unstable airmass. Strong thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon hours and they affected the community of Eagle Mountain. The storms produced gusty and damaging winds, estimated to be at least 60 mph. According to the COOP weather observer in Eagle Mountain, strong thunderstorm winds downed a number of trees and power lines in the area. A Severe Thunderstorm Warning was in effect for the Eagle Mountain area beginning at 1306PST and continuing through 1400PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported 1.24 inches of rain fell in 35 minutes near the intersection of Highway 111 and Indian Trail Road in Rancho Mirage, resulting in 1 foot of water in the roadway at the gutters. The Century Theatre at The River in Rancho Mirage also evacuated movie-goers due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread flooding was reported in the areas of Indio, Indian Wells and Palm Desert due to very heavy rain. The storm channels in Palm Desert, many of which flow through the middle of golf courses, were running swiftly. Large rocks up to soccer ball size and water up to 2 feet deep covered Fred Waring Drive in Indian Wells, stranding one vehicle. The intersections of Avenues 48 and 49 with Monroe and Madison Streets were both covered with a foot or more of water, stalling at least 3 vehicles.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant water flow on Whitewater storm channel through la quinta was reported by the Coachella Valley Water District. The water was contained in channel, but flowed through some golf courses. Waist deep water was reported along some roadways, stalling and nearly submerging several vehicles. A driver noted that the flooding came on quickly, in about 20-20 minutes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of Paisano Road and Cholla Way was washed out and impassable with flash flooding occurring.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The atmosphere across central Riverside county, including Joshua Tree National Park, remained very moist and unstable on August 25th, due in part to lingering moisture from former tropical storm Ivo. Scattered thunderstorms developed across the park during the afternoon hours, primarily affecting the southern portion from the Cottonwood Visitor's Center south to the park exit along Interstate 10. The storms produced very heavy rains; radar indicated rain rates in excess of 2 inches per hour at times. A Flash Flood Warning for central Riverside county was initially issued at 1529PST which included the Cottonwood Visitor's Center. At 1530PST, the park host indicated that flooding had started at the visitor center. Heavy rains and flash flooding continued into the evening and at 1809PST the Flash Flood Warning was re-issued with a new valid time ofl 2030PST. At 1805PST the park service reported ongoing flash flooding. Park rangers were assisting several stranded motorists who were attempting to exit the park. The road between the Visitor's Center and Interstate 10 was closed due to flash flooding, and a road to the north of the center was also washed out preventing an evacuation.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Tropical moisture from former tropical storm Ivo lingered across southeast California on August 25th, and as a result the airmass was very moist and unstable. Due to the very moist nature of the atmosphere, a Flash Flood Watch was in effect. During the late afternoon hours, scattered thunderstorms developed across central Riverside county, including parts of Joshua Tree National Park, and they produced locally heavy rain which led to flash flooding. Flash Flood Warning were then issued beginning at 430 pm; some of the most significant flooding in the park occurred at the Cottonwood Visitor's Center near the south entrance. Multiple roads were closed or washed out, and park rangers assisted several stranded motorists who were attempting to leave the park.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water, debris and boulders were flowing across Highway 62 just north of North Indian Canyon Drive. The area flowing across the highway is 40 feet wide and 6 feet deep.

Highway 62 near Desert Hot Springs was also affected with very a very wide and deep area of flowing water, rocks and debris. Highway S22 near Borrego Springs suffered significant road damage and road closures for up to 24 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported that the 60 freeway was flooded, with 4 or 5 vehicles stuck in flood waters under the Market Street overpass. One motorist reported that the flood waters were moving his vehicle. Lanes 2, 3, and 4 of Highway 91 were flooded, with vehicles flooded out and sliding, including a school bus. Riverside City College cancelled classes due to flooding at the Landis Performing Arts Center and the campus quadrangle. Several other cars were flooded in parking lots near 14th Street, as well as basement flooding at a business there.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant surge of subtropical moisture arrived on the 29th ahead of a weather system coming up from Mexico. Combined with monsoonal moisture from the southeast, this resulted in scattered thunderstorms over the mountains, deserts, and portions of the Inland Empire each afternoon and evening through the 31st. Thunderstorms drifted into the Inland Empire from the adjacent mountains due to the easterly steering flow, as well as along the Elsinore Convergence Zone, in western Riverside County, on the 29th and 30th. The main area of flooding on the 29th occurred in the Riverside area, submerging vehicles and toppling large trees, due to rain-soaked ground and winds. The underpass along 14th Street west of Highway 91 experienced so much rain that it was still flooded the following morning. Though the Riverside Airport did not receive much in the way of rainfall; the gauge at UC Riverside received 1.2 inches of rain. The Inland Empire bore the brunt of the rainfall again on the 30th, adding to the existing flooding issues and creating new ones near Banning and Perris with flooded roadways and an RV park. The flooding in Banning was a debris flow from the Silver Fire burn scar. The only major flooding on the 31st was confined to the high desert along Highway 247 between Reche Road and Lynn Street.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An employee at UC Riverside estimated wind gusts up to 70 mph with very heavy rain and reduced visibility. Nearby, a large tree fell on the Rubidoux Boulevard off-ramp along Highway 60. Several other locations reported branches down, including a large tree that was uprooted and fell on a house along Chapman Street west of Magnolia Avenue.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported minor roadway flooding on Gavilan Road and Esperanza Drive, west of Perris.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reports flooded roadway and debris including rocks on Highway 243 south of Banning. Northbound traffic was closed. Further up the mountain off of 243, the Silent Valley RV Park had stranded residents due debris flows and flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported Orange Avenue from Murrieta Road to Evans Road, just northeast of Perris, was completely flooded and vehicles were not able to make it through. A nearby mesonet station recorded 0.69 inches of rain in 20 minutes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the evening hours across portions of east central Riverside county on September 2nd, and they produced locally heavy rainfall in the areas around Desert Center and Eagle Mountain. Between 1630PST and 1730PST radar indicated that up to 3 inches of rain fell northeast of Desert Center and along State Route 177. At 1830PST, local law enforcement reported that water was running across State Route 177 north of Desert Center, and flash flooding was occurring. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for the area starting at 1745PST and continuing until 2045PST. No injuries were reported due to the flash flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed across portions of Imperial and eastern Riverside county during the afternoon hours on September 2nd, and they continued into the evening. The atmosphere was quite moist and unstable, and as a result the thunderstorms produced both strong gusty outflow winds and locally heavy rainfall. Rainfall rates as estimated by radar exceeded 2 inches per hour at times and led to flash flooding across portions of eastern Riverside county, mainly east of Joshua Tree National Park and in the area between Eagle Mountain and Desert Center. Flooding also impacted roads in the area such as Highway 177 and Interstate 10.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The USGS stream gauge on Palm Canyon Creek reported a 3.19 ft. rise. The gauge peaked at 1400 PST. Downstream from the gauge, broadcast media reported Araby Drive in Palm Springs was shut down due to a wall of water that passed through the area. CHP reported Golf Club Drive was closed at the wash due to flooding. Media also reported a flash flood and debris flow 2 feet deep and 20 feet wide flowing across Golf Club Drive. Cathedral Canyon Drive was closed at Whitewater Wash due to flooding and debris flows. The public also reported a flash flood and debris flow down Tahquitz Creek through the Tahquitz Creek Golf Resort.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered thunderstorms continued over the mountains, deserts, and portions of the Inland Empire, producing flash flooding each afternoon and evening through the 7th, with a brief lull in activity on the 1st. The hot spots on the 3rd were in the San Diego and Riverside County mountains, as well as the Coachella Valley. Storms in the Idyllwild/Pine Cove area produced flash flooding along Highway 243 and hail up to one-half inch. The Palm Springs area experienced flooding due to runoff from storms in the adjacent mountains, closing Araby Drive. Mountain storms also resulted in a flash flood and debris flow that raced down Tahquitz Creek and flowed through the Tahquitz Creek golf resort, closing Cathedral Canyon Drive at the Whitewater Wash. Areas in Riverside County also received accumulating small hail and severe winds from collapsing thunderstorms. Activity on the 4th and 5th favored similar areas, with more flash flooding. Runoff from storms over the Mountain Fire burn area in the San Jacinto Mountains resulted in a flash flood and debris flow 2 feet deep and 20 feet wide across Golf Club Drive in Cathedral City. Heavy rain also caused flooding on Highway 74 at McCall Road in Idyllwild, as well as Interstate 8 between Willows Road and Japatul. On the 6th, mud and water covered Highway S2 near the SR 79 intersection, closing that road due to multiple vehicles stuck in the mud. Pea to dime sized hail and damaging winds also accompanied these storms. Heavy rain caused minor road flooding in the Pine Valley area, with 1 to 2 inches of water flowing over several roadways. Highway 247 at Bessemer Mine Road had a 50-foot wide area of fast-moving water flowing across it, just east of Lucerne Valley. On the 7th, heavy rain near Forest Falls resulted in the normally dry Mill Creek running 2 feet deep and about 50 feet wide, stranding campers on one side of the creek. In San Diego County, there were 5 or 6 spots of water running across Highway 94 between Shockey Truck Trail and Sheridan Road with a maximum water depth of 6 inches. Waves of water up to 8 inches deep, with mud and debris, flowed rapidly over Highway 78 a few miles east of Julian. Highway 78 was impacted again as it dropped down into the desert, with 3 to 8 inches of water, in an area approximately 75 yards wide, flowing across the highway. Golf Club Drive in Cathedral City was closed again due to flooding from the Whitewater Wash.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter was in Idyllwild traveling on Highway 243 to Pine Cove. There was 2 deep of 0.5 hail and 1-3 of water flowing across Highway243. Broken tree branches were all over the roadway from hail damage. A nearby COOP observer reported that the roads turned white, all covered with accumulating hail.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered thunderstorms continued over the mountains, deserts, and portions of the Inland Empire, producing flash flooding each afternoon and evening through the 7th, with a brief lull in activity on the 1st. The hot spots on the 3rd were in the San Diego and Riverside County mountains, as well as the Coachella Valley. Storms in the Idyllwild/Pine Cove area produced flash flooding along Highway 243 and hail up to one-half inch. The Palm Springs area experienced flooding due to runoff from storms in the adjacent mountains, closing Araby Drive. Mountain storms also resulted in a flash flood and debris flow that raced down Tahquitz Creek and flowed through the Tahquitz Creek golf resort, closing Cathedral Canyon Drive at the Whitewater Wash. Areas in Riverside County also received accumulating small hail and severe winds from collapsing thunderstorms. Activity on the 4th and 5th favored similar areas, with more flash flooding. Runoff from storms over the Mountain Fire burn area in the San Jacinto Mountains resulted in a flash flood and debris flow 2 feet deep and 20 feet wide across Golf Club Drive in Cathedral City. Heavy rain also caused flooding on Highway 74 at McCall Road in Idyllwild, as well as Interstate 8 between Willows Road and Japatul. On the 6th, mud and water covered Highway S2 near the SR 79 intersection, closing that road due to multiple vehicles stuck in the mud. Pea to dime sized hail and damaging winds also accompanied these storms. Heavy rain caused minor road flooding in the Pine Valley area, with 1 to 2 inches of water flowing over several roadways. Highway 247 at Bessemer Mine Road had a 50-foot wide area of fast-moving water flowing across it, just east of Lucerne Valley. On the 7th, heavy rain near Forest Falls resulted in the normally dry Mill Creek running 2 feet deep and about 50 feet wide, stranding campers on one side of the creek. In San Diego County, there were 5 or 6 spots of water running across Highway 94 between Shockey Truck Trail and Sheridan Road with a maximum water depth of 6 inches. Waves of water up to 8 inches deep, with mud and debris, flowed rapidly over Highway 78 a few miles east of Julian. Highway 78 was impacted again as it dropped down into the desert, with 3 to 8 inches of water, in an area approximately 75 yards wide, flowing across the highway. Golf Club Drive in Cathedral City was closed again due to flooding from the Whitewater Wash.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported water flowing across the roadway along state route 74 E / state route 371 in Mountain Center. The road is impassable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported a debris flow on Highway 74 at McCall Park Road. The water cleared out soon after and left behind debris on the road...such as rocks and sticks. The nearby Keenwild mesonet recorded 0.47 inches of rain during this time.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant heavy rain on the 3rd through 5th resulted in devastating flooding and debris flows in the canyon of the Riverside Mountains where the Zen Mountain Center is located. The Center sustained heavy damage from debris flows on the 4th and 5th and it is unclear which particular day was worse. On the 4th, approximately 3 to 5 feet of mud and rocks flowed through the retreat, half-burying cars and cabins. On the 5th, the second flow brought several more feet of mud and debris, fully burying a few cars. The flows broke plumbing pipes and uncovered buried phone lines. The various buildings sustained significant damage as well, with several feet of mud inside and water damage. Much of the walkways and common areas were unrecognizable due to the washouts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across portions of Joshua Tree National Park during the early afternoon hours, and they affected much of the northwestern portion of the park, from Keys View northward towards the park entrances. Heavy rain began to fall after 1200PST and radar indicated rainfall rates in excess of 2 inches per hour at times. According to the Park Service, heavy rain caused flash flooding along Keys View road; debris spread onto the roadway and the road had to be closed at 1248PST. Also, they reported campground closures due to the flash flooding. Both Sheep Pass and Jumbo Rocks campgrounds were closed by about 1318PST. People were stranded on area roads and in the campgrounds due to water flowing over the roads. Flash Flood Warnings were issued for Joshua Tree National Park starting at 1206PST and continuing through 1530PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across Joshua Tree National Park during the early afternoon hours on September 7th. Due to the very moist and unstable nature of the atmosphere, the thunderstorms produced locally heavy rainfall with rain rates well in excess of one inch per hour. Flash flooding developed across portions of the park, primarily the northwestern sections from Keys View northward. Heavy rains caused flooding in area campgrounds such as Sheep Pass and Jumbo Rocks, and they also caused the north entrance to be closed. No injuries were reported as a result of the flash flooding. Flash Flood Warnings were issued for the park due to the heavy rains and flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across portions of Joshua Tree National Park during the early afternoon hours on September 7th, and they primarily affected the northwestern portion of the park, from Keys View northward towards the park entrances. Due to the very moist and unstable nature of the atmosphere, the storms produced locally heavy rain which led to flash flooding in the park. The rains began around 1200PST and by 1330PST, radar indicated that 2 to 3 inches of rain had fallen near and to the north of Keys View. According to the Park Service, at 1330PST Barker Dam near Keys View Road had substantial flow; flash flooding measured 20 feet wide and 3 feet deep. In addition, the north entrance to the Park and Queen Valley Road were closed through 1700PST due to the flooding. A Flash Flood Warning was issued for the park beginning at 1206PST and continuing through 1530PST. No injuries were reported due to the flash flooding.

Flash Flood Warnings were issued for the park due to the heavy rains and flooding.
