EVENT_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed across far eastern portions of Riverside county during the afternoon hours on September 8th. The thunderstorms generated strong, gusty and eventually damaging outflow winds estimated to be at least 60 mph in strength. One of the stronger storms affected the community of Blythe. Local law enforcement reported that power poles were blown down near the intersection of State Route 78 and 16th Avenue, about 4 miles east southeast of the Blythe airport. A Severe Thunderstorm Warning was issued for the Blythe area starting at 1335PST  and continuing until 1430PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed across portions of eastern Riverside county during the afternoon hours on September 8th. Due to the rather moist and unstable nature of the atmosphere, the storms were able to generate gusty outflow winds strong enough to blow down power poles. Most of the thunderstorms formed over open country, however a few were able to affect communities such as Blythe. Severe Thunderstorm Warnings were issued as a result of the strong convection.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts downed nine power poles in Bermuda Dunes. Estimated wind gusts 50 to 55 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon thunderstorms erupted once more, with gusty downdraft winds, downing power lines and poles in the Coachella Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet station around 1400 PST on the 21st and gusted at or above 58 mph  off and on through 0200 PST on the 22nd. During this time, winds gusted over 60 mph several times, including the peak gust of 65 mph measured consistently between 0145 and 0200 PST on the 22nd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad trough of low pressure moved through the desert southwest on the 21st and 22nd, providing strong, gusty northwest winds to the mountains and deserts, especially the Coachella Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sky Valley mesonet station reported winds gusts over 58 mph off and on from 0500-0700 PST on the 4th. During this time, a peak wind gust of 60 mph was measured twice between 0652 and 0702 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of surface high pressure built in over the Great Basin, creating approximately 14 millibars of offshore flow from Salt Lake City to the coast of San Diego. This led to temperatures in the low to mid 90s at the coast and strong gusty winds over the mountain ridges and through aligned canyons and passes. Riverside and Orange County were primarily affected on the 4th, then San Diego County on the 5th as the wind shifted more easterly. No wind damage was reported, but the strong winds led to the spread of the De Luz Fire on the Camp Pendleton marine base.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fremont Canyon RAWS reported winds gusts over 60 mph between 0600-1100 PST on the 4th. During this time, a peak wind gust of 66 mph was measured 0651 and 0751 PST. The Pleasants Peak mesonet station reported winds gusts over 58 mph between 0700-1130 PST on the 4th. During this time, a peak wind gust of 61 mph was measured between 0901 and 0931 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of surface high pressure built in over the Great Basin, creating approximately 14 millibars of offshore flow from Salt Lake City to the coast of San Diego. This led to temperatures in the low to mid 90s at the coast and strong gusty winds over the mountain ridges and through aligned canyons and passes. Riverside and Orange County were primarily affected on the 4th, then San Diego County on the 5th as the wind shifted more easterly. No wind damage was reported, but the strong winds led to the spread of the De Luz Fire on the Camp Pendleton marine base.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pleasants Peak mesonet station reported winds gusts over 58 mph between 0100 and 1030 PST on the 5th. During this time, a peak wind gust of 62 mph was measured between 0830 and 0900 PST.|The Sky Valley mesonet station reported winds gusts over 58 mph between midnight and 0200 PST on the 5th. During this time, a peak wind gust of 59 mph was measured between 0652 and 0702 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of surface high pressure built in over the Great Basin, creating approximately 14 millibars of offshore flow from Salt Lake City to the coast of San Diego. This led to temperatures in the low to mid 90s at the coast and strong gusty winds over the mountain ridges and through aligned canyons and passes. Riverside and Orange County were primarily affected on the 4th, then San Diego County on the 5th as the wind shifted more easterly. No wind damage was reported, but the strong winds led to the spread of the De Luz Fire on the Camp Pendleton marine base.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sky Valley mesonet station reported wind gusts over 58 mph off and on from 2000 PST on the 8th to 0400 PST on the 9th, with several gusts over 60 mph. During this time, a peak gust of 78 mph was recorded twice between 0222 and 0232 PST on the 9th. The Whitewater RAWS station reported a peak gust of 60 mph between 0150 and 0250 PST on the 9th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong, upper-level low pressure system moved through southern California with gusty westerly winds along the mountain ridges and down the desert slopes. There were three periods of enhanced winds over the mountain ridges and through the aligned passes, with gusts 55-75 mph. Visibility was reduced in the Coachella Valley below the San Gorgonio Pass due to blowing sand and dust. No damage was reported, however. This event was also the first significant precipitation event of the winter season. The rainfall was likely a factor in the 318 accidents that occurred during the event, versus a normal day of 75 accidents.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sky Valley mesonet station reported wind gusts over 58 mph from 2300 PST on the 27th to 1600 PST on the 28th, with a couple short breaks. Most gusts were over 65 mph. During this time, a peak gust of 85 mph was recorded twice between 0412 and 0422 PST on the 28th. The Whitewater RAWS station reported wind gusts over 58 mph from 2150 PST on the 27th to 0950 PST on the 28th. During this time, a peak gust of 65 mph was recorded twice between 0350 and 0550 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong, upper-level low moved down the West Coast on the 27th, through the 28th. Strong to severe, pre-frontal, southwest to west winds impacted the northern desert slopes before a powerful 130 knot jet moved around the backside of the low and through southern California, increasing westerly winds in the mountains and lower deserts through the 29th. Several locations reported gusts above 65 mph, with a highest wind gust measured of 85 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two vehicles stuck in approximately 3 feet of moving water and mud at the intersection of San Timoteo canyon road and Live Oak Canyon Road. One trapped person was extricated around 1500 PST. One of the motorists stated that there is a natural waterway that runs down the canyon, but the water broke through, flooding the streets. Parts of San Timoteo Canyon Road from Live Oak Canyon Road to Barton Road were closed as a result.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold, upper-level closed low developed along the Central Coast and drifted south before stalling over southern California on the 23rd. Heavy showers began in the northern areas, spreading slowly south into San Diego County. The focus of the precipitation was over and west of the mountains on the 21st, as the low center just west of Oceanside drove southwesterly flow into the area. For the 22nd into the 23rd, the low shifted directly over San Diego, changing the flow to east/southeast and bringing the precipitation focus to the desert slopes and mountain ridges. Three-day storm total rainfall saw one quarter of an inch to one inch of rain for the coast and valley locations of Orange and San Diego Counties, while the Inland Empire saw up to 2.75 inches of rain on the slopes of the San Bernardino Mountains. Several roads were closed due to flooding in the Inland Empire, stalling a few vehicles and requiring swift water rescues. Heavy rain draining into a canyon near Moreno valley on the 21st resulted in flash flooding across a roadway, trapping vehicles and at least one person. The combination of one inch of rainfall in one hour and a storm pump failure resulted in flooding and a major rescue in the San Diego ���Midway��� area on the 21st as well. Very heavy rain near the Mexican Border on the 22nd caused several instances of flooding in the Tijuana River basin. A thunderstorm coming onshore near Solana Beach produced periods of dime to nickel-sized hail according to the lifeguards. The lower deserts were more varied in amounts ranging from one tenth of an inch to near three-quarters of an inch. The snow level started around 7000 feet on the 21st and dropped to 4000-5000 feet by the morning of the 22nd. Most locations above 4000 feet reported 1 to 3 inches of snow. However there were a few standout locations with heavy snow. Wrightwood, in the San Bernardino Mountains measured 11 to 13 inches at 6040 feet (spotter report). Pine Cove, in the Riverside County Mountains, measured 9 inches of snow at 6200 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Bernardino Sun reported that firefighters from Colton, San Bernardino and Riverside were called to the Santa Ana River bed, near the intersection of Riverside Avenue and Key Street around 1900 PST, to rescue five homeless people trapped in the normally dry channel by rapidly rising flood waters. One man was trapped in a tree and had to be rescued by helicopter. The other four were rescued from a small island just down-river of the other man, once flood waters had receded. The man in the tree was treated at a hospital for minor hypothermia, but the others were uninjured.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported roadway flooding along east La Candena Drive, a frontage road of Interstate 215. A 500-600 foot swath of 1 foot-deep, standing water covered the roadway, stalling at least one vehicle.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet between 0147-0152 PST on the 4th and ended between 0417 and 0422 PST. During this time, winds gusted mainly over 60 mph, with a few lulls in the 50s. A peak gust of 74 mph was measured several times between 0200-0215 PST and again between 0400-0415 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold, upper-level trough of low pressure brought gusty west winds, and scattered showers to the mountains and San Diego County foothills on the 4th. Most areas that saw rain measured a quarter of an inch or less, but some up-slope foothill locations in San Diego County measured up to one-half of an inch. The snow level dropped to around 3000 feet, with a trace to two inches of snow measured from I-8 to Big Bear. Pine Valley schools were closed on the 4th and chain control was enforced around the Big Bear and Pine Cove areas. The strongest winds were fairly well distributed over the area with several gusts above 60 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Toro Peak mesonet between 0215-0245 PST on the 4th. During this time, sustained winds were 55 mph with peak gusts of 62 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold, upper-level trough of low pressure brought gusty west winds, and scattered showers to the mountains and San Diego County foothills on the 4th. Most areas that saw rain measured a quarter of an inch or less, but some up-slope foothill locations in San Diego County measured up to one-half of an inch. The snow level dropped to around 3000 feet, with a trace to two inches of snow measured from I-8 to Big Bear. Pine Valley schools were closed on the 4th and chain control was enforced around the Big Bear and Pine Cove areas. The strongest winds were fairly well distributed over the area with several gusts above 60 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet between 1536-1541 PST on the 7th and ended between 1936-1941 PST the same day. During this time, winds gusted over 60 mph off and on, with a peak gust of 73 mph measured between 1541-1546 PST and a secondary peak gust of 72 mph between 1651-1701 PST. |High winds occurred at the Boyd Deep Canyon mesonet between 1900-1930 PST on the 7th. During this time, winds were sustained 30-35 mph with gusts 60-64 mph with the peak gust of 64 mph measured between 1500-1510 PST. |High winds occurred at the Whitewater RAWS between 1850-2050 PST on the 7th. During this time, winds were sustained around 40 mph with a peak gust of 58 mph measured between 1950-2050 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the 7th, a deep trough of low pressure dug southward through the Great Basin, bringing gusty winds, rain, mountain snow and a reinforcing shot of cold air to the region. The coast and valley locations measured between one-tenth and one-third of an inch, with up to 1.5 inches of rain in the foothills of the San Bernardino County mountains. The snow level was higher with this event, hovering around 5000 feet. Snowfall reports were generally 2 to 8 inches, with the heaviest amounts in Pine Cove and Running Springs. The strongest westerly winds occurred in the mountains of San Diego and Riverside Counties with several peak gusts over 65 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0551-0651 PST and ended between 1451-1551 PST on the 9th. During this time, winds gusted mostly above 60 mph with a peak gust of 86 mph measured between 1051-1151 PST.|High winds began at the Pleasants Peak mesonet between 0431-0500 PST and ended between 2230-2300 PST on the 9th. During this time, winds gusted above 60 mph off and on with a peak gust of 73 mph measured between 1230-1300 PST.|A nearby spotter reported wind gusts snapped a 36-inch diameter wooden transmission pole at its base on Orangethorpe between Lakeview and Richfield. The 60-foot tall pole was prevented from falling to the ground because the transmission lines kept it suspended above the ground. Police and Southern California Edison responded.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 1042 mb high built in over Nevada on the 9th as the low moved off to the east with a 20-25 mb offshore pressure gradient setting up from Salt Lake City to San Diego. This produces gusty northeast winds and cool, dry air for southern California through the 10th. The San Diego County mountains and foothills were again the most windy areas for this event with gusts over 65 mph.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Highland Springs RAWS between 1116-1416 PST on the 9th. During this time, winds gusted over 59 mph with a peak gust of 60 mph measured between 1216-1316 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 1042 mb high built in over Nevada on the 9th as the low moved off to the east with a 20-25 mb offshore pressure gradient setting up from Salt Lake City to San Diego. This produces gusty northeast winds and cool, dry air for southern California through the 10th. The San Diego County mountains and foothills were again the most windy areas for this event with gusts over 65 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Pleasants Peak mesonet between 0230-0300 PST and ended between 1100-1130 PST on the 14th. During this time, winds were sustained 40-50 mph out of the east-northeast, gusting mostly above 60 mph. The peak gust of 72 mph was measured between 0500-0530 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure peaked at 1045 mb over western Utah(similar in strength to December 9-10 event, which was centered in eastern Nevada) and appeared to be diurnally enhanced due to strong radiational cooling in the Utah desert. This setup resulted in moderate to locally strong Santa Ana winds. The winds developed in the mountains and spread into the inland valleys and coastal areas of Orange county on the 14th, with strengthening winds in San Diego County late in the day. A secondary peak of offshore winds occurred the night of the 14th through midday on the 15th with the strongest winds across the Riverside and San Diego County mountains and foothills. The highest wind gusts were observed in the mountains and foothills of San Diego County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Sky Valley mesonet between 0557-0612 PST on the 14th. During this time, a peak gust of 72 mph was recorded, along with 2 other gusts of 62 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure peaked at 1045 mb over western Utah(similar in strength to December 9-10 event, which was centered in eastern Nevada) and appeared to be diurnally enhanced due to strong radiational cooling in the Utah desert. This setup resulted in moderate to locally strong Santa Ana winds. The highest wind gusts were observed in the mountains and foothills of San Diego County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Sky Valley mesonet between 0300-0400 PST on the 19th with a peak gust of 63 mph recorded during that period.|High winds occurred at the Whitewater RAWS mesonet between 0350-0450 PST on the 19th with a peak gust of 60 mph recorded during that period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong, upper-level trough brought colder weather along with rain, mountain snow and gusty southwest to west winds to the region. Light rain began during the early morning on the 19th, with most precipitation ending west of the mountains later that night. Showers lingered over the mountains and deserts into the 20th, as moisture wrapped around the surface low pressure system, exiting to the southeast. Coastal and inland valley locations generally received between one-tenth and one-half of an inch of rain, with up to one inch in the coastal foothills of San Diego and San Bernardino Counties. The upper deserts varied widely from no rain in Victorville to one-half inch at the Mojave Dam. Only a few hundredths were reported in the Coachella Valley. Snow levels lowered to 3500 to 4000 feet, bringing 2 to 5 inches of snow to mountain locations above 4500 feet and trace amounts below. Chains were required on Palomar Mountain. This was the last significant precipitation until late January of 2014. Cold air instability also resulted in scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon of the 19th in the valleys and high desert. Very small hail and flooding was reported by a spotter in Anaheim on Miraloma Street between Fee Ana Street and Lakeview, where water flooded over the curbs and in the intersection up to 6 inches deep in places. A spotter in Phelan sent photos of small hail covering their yard. The Coachella Valley saw the highest wind gusts overnight and into the morning of the 19th, with a few in the San Diego County mountains as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0350-0450 PST and ended between 0851-0951 PST on the 25th. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east at 40-50 mph with several gusts over 60 mph. The peak gust of 69 mph was measured between 0451-0551 PST. |High winds occurred at the Pleasants Peak mesonet between 0700-0900 PST on the 25th with a peak gust of 62 mph during that period.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface pressure gradients due to high pressure over the Great Basin produced locally gusty high winds from the east and northeast, mainly in the mountains and western foothills of the San Diego County mountains on the 23rd and 25th, with a lull on the 24th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Pleasants Peak mesonet between 0500-0530 PST and ended between 1100-1130 PST on the 29th. During this time, winds were out of the northeast and east-northeast with gusts over 60 mph and several over 70 mph. The peak gust of 78 mph was measured twice between 0700-0900 PST.|High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0551-0651 PST and ended between 1051-1151 PST on the 29th. During this time, winds were out of the east-northeast sustained around 40 mph with a peak gust of 70 mph was measured twice between 0751-0851 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There was one last round of north to northeast winds to end the year with 1036 mb surface high pressure rebuilding over Utah on the 29th, resulting in a 25 mb pressure gradient from Salt Lake City to San Diego. This event was not as widespread as those earlier in the month. The highest winds occurred where mountain waves surfaced below the Cajon pass and the Santa Ana Mountains and foothills.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0000 and 0051 PST and ended between 1551 and 1651 PST on the 14th. During this time, winds were sustained 40 mph or higher with most gusts over 65 mph A peak gust of 77 mph was measured between 0351 and 0451 PST. Nearby, fiber optic lines were downed on Santiago Canyon Road in the vicinity of Portola Hills.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure built over the Great Basin created strong, gusty northeast winds in the mountains, western foothills and inland valleys, with the strongest winds on the 13th and 14th. The highest wind gusts occurred in the San Diego County foothills and inland Orange County, including the Santa Ana Mountains. Winds toppled trees near San Bernadino, and downed fiber optic lines near Santiago Canyon in Orange County.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds toppled a tree at Mt. Vernon elementary school in San Bernardino, damaging the roof of an administration building. Wind gusts were 55 mph in the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure built over the Great Basin created strong, gusty northeast winds in the mountains, western foothills and inland valleys, with the strongest winds on the 13th and 14th. The highest wind gusts occurred in the San Diego County foothills and inland Orange County, including the Santa Ana Mountains. Winds toppled trees near San Bernadino, and downed fiber optic lines near Santiago Canyon in Orange County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sky Valley mesonet recorded wind gusts of 58 mph between 1551 and 1601 PST on the 14th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure built over the Great Basin created strong, gusty northeast winds in the mountains, western foothills and inland valleys, with the strongest winds on the 13th and 14th. The highest wind gusts occurred in the San Diego County foothills and inland Orange County, including the Santa Ana Mountains. Winds toppled trees near San Bernadino, and downed fiber optic lines near Santiago Canyon in Orange County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Sky Valley mesonet between 1611-1616 PST on the 30th and ended between 2026-2031 PST that evening. During this period, winds were sustained over 40 mph with gusts over 65 mph, and several in the 70s. A peak gust of 88 mph was recorded twice between 1906-1906 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure moving across central California brought strong west winds to the mountains and deserts from the evening of the 30th through the morning of the 31st. Sustained winds of 25 to 35 mph and gusts to 60 mph...locally higher were observed. Burns Canyon in the upper desert and Sky Valley in the Coachella Valley were the big hot spots. In addition, high astronomical tides and elevated surf due to the storm resulted in minor coastal flooding near Imperial Beach in San Diego County, closing a couple streets.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Sierra Peak mesonet reported high winds between 0730-1630 PST on the 28th, with a peak gust of 69 mph recorded between 0904-1004 PST. The El Cariso RAWS also reported a peak gust of 70 mph between 1520 and 1620 PST that afternoon.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak, upper-level trough moved through California overnight on February 26th, into the morning of the 27th, increasing gusty west winds and bringing a round of light to moderate showers over and west of the mountains. A much stronger, Pacific low pressure system took aim at southern California late on the 27th, bringing periods of heavy rain and high-elevation mountain snow through the 28th (with additional heavy rain through March 1). Most of the upslope rain and convective showers occurred on the 28th. Strong, long-duration upslope flow enhanced rainfall on southwest-facing coastal slopes. The four-day, storm total precipitation amounts were significant. Costal locations ranged from 1 to 3 inches of rain, with the valleys recording up to 4.5 inches toward the coastal slopes. Mountain locations varied widely depending on slope aspect, but most recorded between 3 and 8 inches of rain. The upper deserts recorded between one-tenth and one-half inch, while the lower deserts measured generally less than one-tenth of an inch. The notable exceptions were Palm Springs, Desert Hot Springs in the Coachella Valley and San Felipe in San Diego County, all of which measured between one-half of an inch and one inch. The big rainfall winners were along the southern slopes of the San Bernardino County mountains, with Yucaipa Ridge coming in at 11.11 inches, Lytle Creek with 9.67 inches and Cedar Glen with 9.10 inches. The snow level remained fairly high, around 6000 feet. Most locations saw between 2 and 7 inches of snow, with Big Bear Lake and Onyx Peak recording 9 to 10 inches. The significant rainfall in a relatively short period of time resulted in numerous instances of urban and flash flooding with mud/debris flows, causing numerous road closures and swift water rescues in and around the urban areas of Orange, (Anaheim), San Diego (Escondido and Fashion Valley), and Riverside (Fallbrook to Lake Elsinore) counties. The most significant of these was the mud slides and subsequent road closure of Highway 74 (Ortega Highway) stemming from the Falls Fire burn scar. Many road closures also occurred in the Coachella Valley as a result of heavy rainfall over the headwaters of the Whitewater River, flowing down the valley through the storm channel. Area rivers saw rises of 2 to 5 feet, in some instances within 12 hours. A 10 to 15-foot-tall and eight-foot-wide section of the quarter-mile levee protecting Buckwheat Road from Sheep Creek failed, threatening 8 homes with flood waters. Westerly winds with this system were significant as well, topping numerous large trees and power poles, as well as damage at John Wayne Airport. A report of a 102 mph wind gust came from the Bear Mountain ski resort weather equipment on the 28th. Conditions support this gust, however, no damage was reported. Thunderstorms on the 28th also produced gusty winds, downing several trees and damaging power lines and other structures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Riverside County OES reported Ortega Highway (Hwy 74) closed due to debris flow of mud around the Falls Fire burn scar. A sink hole was also reported on Grand Avenue.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Highland Springs RAWS measured a peak gust of 65 mph from a line of thunderstorms between 1616 and 1716 PST on the 28th.

The upper deserts recorded between one-tenth and one-half inch, while the lower deserts measured generally less than one-tenth of an inch. The notable exceptions were Palm Springs, Desert Hot Springs in the Coachella Valley and San Felipe in San Diego County, all of which measured between one-half of an inch and one inch. The big rainfall winners were along the southern slopes of the San Bernardino County mountains, with Yucaipa Ridge coming in at 11.11 inches, Lytle Creek with 9.67 inches and Cedar Glen with 9.10 inches. The snow level remained fairly high, around 6000 feet. Most locations saw between 2 and 7 inches of snow, with Big Bear Lake and Onyx Peak recording 9 to 10 inches. The significant rainfall in a relatively short period of time resulted in numerous instances of urban and flash flooding with mud/debris flows, causing numerous road closures and swift water rescues in and around the urban areas of Orange, (Anaheim), San Diego (Escondido and Fashion Valley), and Riverside (Fallbrook to Lake Elsinore) counties. The most significant of these was the mud slides and subsequent road closure of Highway 74 (Ortega Highway) stemming from the Falls Fire burn scar. Many road closures also occurred in the Coachella Valley as a result of heavy rainfall over the headwaters of the Whitewater River, flowing down the valley through the storm channel. Area rivers saw rises of 2 to 5 feet, in some instances within 12 hours. A 10 to 15-foot-tall and eight-foot-wide section of the quarter-mile levee protecting Buckwheat Road from Sheep Creek failed, threatening 8 homes with flood waters. Westerly winds with this system were significant as well, topping numerous large trees and power poles, as well as damage at John Wayne Airport. A report of a 102 mph wind gust came from the Bear Mountain ski resort weather equipment on the 28th. Conditions support this gust, however, no damage was reported. Thunderstorms on the 28th also produced gusty winds, downing several trees and damaging power lines and other structures.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reports Bridge Street at Gillman Springs Road closed due to flooding from heavy rain.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The strong upper level low pressure system that brought damaging wind and flooding on February 28, continued to produce bands of rain and snow, along with gusty winds through March 1. The majority of the flooding occurred on February 28th, but minor street flooding was still being reported from continued rain on March 1 from Riverside to Vista and San Diego as areas of heavy rain occurred during the morning of March 1st and then was followed by a continuous line of heavy showers and isolated thunderstorms late in the afternoon. Additional rain on March 1 resulted in flooding in Oceanside, Temecula, Sea World San Diego, as well as minor street flooding in Mission Viejo and a few other locations. Road closures remained in effect near Forest Falls due to a major debris flow that occurred the afternoon and evening of February 28th. Numerous power outages continued into the 1st for many residents in the San Bernardino County mountains as well. Up to 8 inches of snow was reported in the San Bernardino County mountains as well. Strong onshore winds combined with a large west-southwest swell to generate high surf along the San Diego and Orange County beaches with strong rip currents on the 1st as well.

The Pierce Fire began around 1537 PST on the 15th near the intersection of Avenue 66 and Pierce Street in Thermal. Initially reported at 10 acres, the fire burned at a moderate rate of spread through medium to heavy brush, increasing rapidly to 200 acres over just a few hours. Road closures were in effect along north and southbound Highway 86 between Avenue 86 and Avenue 80, as well as Avenue 66 from Avenue 86 to Pierce Street. The fire burned a total of 350 acres before being fully contained at 2234 PST on the 15th. The fire downed power lines in the area and destroyed one outbuilding. No injuries to firefighters or civilians were reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Edom Hill SDGE mesonet between 2150 PST on the 25th and 0050 PST on the 26th. At this time, a first peak gust of 62 mph was recorded, followed by a period of sub-criteria winds. High winds resumed between 0950 and 1050 PST on the 26th, ending between 1850 and 1950 PST that evening. During this second period, a peak gust of 82 mph was recorded around 1600 PST. Several other gusts over 70 mph were recorded as well. High winds also occurred at the Whitewater RAWS between 0450 and 1850 PST on the 26th. During this time, a peak gust of 63 mph was measured between 0750 and 0850 PST.|Three jets headed into Palm Springs airport were diverted to Los Angeles and Ontario due to strong wind shear and rotors over KPSP between 0925  and 0931 PST. Pilots also reported extreme turbulence over Palm Springs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep, upper-level trough brought strong and gusty westerly winds to the mountains and deserts. Several wind gusts over 75 mph were observed, especially on the desert slopes leading down into the Coachella Valley. This resulted in areas of blowing dust and sand on the desert floor, reducing visibility to near zero at times.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: According to CHP, multiple cars crashed on Highway 86 near Thermal/Mecca due to zero visibility from high winds blowing dust. CHP issued a sig alert following the crash and all southbound lanes on Highway 86 were closed. KTRM airport at the time was reporting winds WSW 22 mph with gusts to 37 mph. The Coachella weather observation had NW winds 15 mph, gusting to 31 mph.|Near Palm Springs, Gene Autry Trail and Vista Chino are both closed at the wash due to low visibilty from blowing dust. Winds at the time: Edom Hill was NW at 50 mph with gusts to 68 mph, while KPSP airport was NE at 25 mph with gusts 38 mph.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep, upper-level trough brought strong and gusty westerly winds to the mountains and deserts. Several wind gusts over 75 mph were observed, especially on the desert slopes leading down into the Coachella Valley. This resulted in areas of blowing dust and sand on the desert floor, reducing visibility to near zero at times.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Edom Hill mesonet between 1050 PST on the 12th and 0150 PST on the 13th. During this time, winds were sustained 40 to 50 mph with a peak gust of 73 mph recorded between 1750 and 1850 PST on the 13th. |High winds occurred at the Whitewater RAWS between 2050 PST on the 12th and 0400 PST on the 13th. During this time, winds were sustained 35 to 45 mph with a peak gust of 66 mph recorded between 0050 and 0150 PST on the 13th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low moved inland across southern California on the 12th, increasing onshore flow and creating strong, gusty westerly winds for the mountains and deserts. Strongest winds were reported in the northern Coachella Valley.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Rancho Cucamonga measured a 60 mph wind gust which downed several small tree limbs.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong 1036 mb surface high pressure built over the Great Basin resulting in two main periods of gusty northeast to east winds over the coastal slopes and inland valleys during the early mornings to early afternoons. Strong winds downed several trees across the mountain foothill and eastern valley areas, as well as power lines just north of Descanso in San Diego County. Significant impacts occurred at US Border Patrol check points on I-8 where large signs were blown over, trees downed and a semi overturned. Widespread gusts over 60 mph (25 locations in San Diego County) were reported with gusts up to around 100 mph in the favored spots like Sill Hill (just west of Cuyamaca Lake) and Buckman Springs in San Diego County and Fremont Canyon in Orange County. This was the strongest and most widespread wind event in several years.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0551 and 0651 PST on the 29th and ended between 1051 and 1151 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east at 40 to 45 mph with a peak gust of 66 mph recorded twice between 0751 and 0951 PST.|High winds began at the Pleasants Peak mesonet between 0530 and 0600 PST on the 29th and ended between 1200 and 1230 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east-northeast around 45 to 55 mph with a peak gust of 76 mph recorded between 0700 and 0730 PST.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Etiwanda fire began on April 30th around 0700 PST in the San Bernardino National Forest near Rancho Cucamonga in San Bernardino County. The fire was due to an escaped illegal campfire a few days prior, when strong winds blew embers that ignited in Day Canyon. A mandatory evacuation order was issued for Rancho Cucamonga residents from Haven Avenue to Carnelian Street, north of Hillside Road, as well as the area West of Etiwanda, North of Wilson and East of Day Creek Wash. Schools evacuated included Day Creek Intermediate School, Los Osos High School, Heritage Intermediate School and Caryn Elementary. The fire burned rapidly south, threatening 600-800 structures. 2143 acres before being fully contained on May 6. Three firefighters sustained unknown minor injuries and one structure was damaged.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Cabazon RAWS between 0514 and 0914 PST on the 30th. During this time, winds were sustained 30 to 35 mph, with a peak gust of 64 mph measured between 0614 and 0714 PST. A spotter in Hemet measured a 50 mph wind gust, small trees snapped or uprooted, and many roof tiles blowing off of houses.  The Ontario airport ASOS recorded a wind gust of 69 mph around 0645 PST and a 70 mph gust between 0851 and 0951 PST on the 30th.  The Chino airport ASOS measured a peak gust of 59 mph around 0906 PST on the 30th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Pleasants Peak mesonet between 0800 and 1000 PST on the 1st. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east around 45 mph, with a peak gust of 63 mph measured between 0900 and 0930 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure over the Great Basin continued the hot and dry Santa Ana winds that began April 29. The winds on this day were focused in the mountains of San Diego County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Edom Hill mesonet around 1500 PST on the 10th and ended around 0600 PST on the 11th. During this time, several gusts over 65 mph were reported, including a peak gust of 83 mph measured between 2000 and 2100 PST on the 10th. Higher gusts may have been reported after this time, but the last high gust appeared to have damaged the wind sensor. Downwind, Palm Springs law enforcement closed Vista Chino, as well as Indian Canyon Road and Gene Autry Road just south of Interstate 10 due to high winds and blowing sand overnight, into the morning of the 11th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough of low pressure deepened and moved across the Great Basin, increasing the onshore flow, resulting in gusty west to northwest winds in the mountains and passes. The winds extended down the desert slopes as well, into the Coachella Valley, creating reduced visibilities and closed roads due to wind gusts in the low 80s and blowing dust and sand.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Santiago Peak mesonet between 0530 and 1030 PST on the 11th. During this time, winds were sustained out of the NNE at 40-45 mph with a peak gust of 59 mph measured between 0930-1000 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough of low pressure deepened and moved across the Great Basin, increasing the onshore flow, resulting in gusty west to northwest winds in the mountains and passes. The winds extended down the desert slopes as well, into the Coachella Valley, creating reduced visibilities and closed roads due to wind gusts in the low 80s and blowing dust and sand.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pleasants Peak mesonet recorded a peak wind gust out of 58 mph out of the east-northeast between 0430-0500 PST on the 12th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure over the Great Basin brought very strong and gusty northeast to east winds and hot weather from the 12th through the 14th, before the winds finally decreased. The hardest hit areas were the mountains and western foothills of Riverside and San Diego County. The gusty winds downed countless trees, power lines and blew tiles from roofs. The winds also helped to fuel and spread nearly a dozen wildfires in San Diego County alone. The hot weather even spawned a damaging dust devil early on, before the winds really got going.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A ham operator reported strong winds blew off one-quarter of the tiles from a structure just northwest of Hemet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Highland Springs RAWS between 0615-0715 PST on the 14th and ended between 1116-1216 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east at 30-45 mph with gusts around 60 mph. A peak gust of 68 mph was recorded between 0716-0816 PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Pleasants Peak mesonet between 0630-0900 PST on the 14th. Winds were sustained out of the east to east-northeast at 30-45 mph with gusts over 65 mph, including the peak gust of 65 mph recorded between 0700-0730 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure over the Great Basin brought very strong and gusty northeast to east winds and hot weather from the 12th through the 14th, before the winds finally decreased. The hardest hit areas were the mountains and western foothills of Riverside and San Diego County. The gusty winds downed countless trees, power lines and blew tiles from roofs. The winds also helped to fuel and spread nearly a dozen wildfires in San Diego County alone. The hot weather even spawned a damaging dust devil early on, before the winds really got going.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Edom Hill mesonet station between 1800-2200 PST on the 16th. During this time, winds were sustained out of the northwest at 37-41 mph, with a peak gust of 60 mph recorded between 1750-1850 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system, moving inland through the Pacific Northwest and northern Rockies, created strong onshore flow over southern California with periods of gusty westerly winds in the mountains and deserts for the 16th and 17th. The winds were strongest each day from late afternoon to late at night. Strongest winds were 20 to 30 mph, with gusts to 65 mph in the windiest locations.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two structures were damaged. One roof collapsed and one roof had damage near the intersection of Calimesa Blvd and Interstate 10.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An inverted upper-level trough lifted north from Baja, Mexico, and along with significant moisture flux (PW of 1.8 inches) helped initiate thunderstorms in easterly steering flow along and just west of the mountain ridgeline. An upper-level trough enhanced thunderstorm intensity and coverage on the afternoon of the 4th and morning of the 5th. Subsidence behind the upper-level wave acted to suppress convection for the latter half of the 5th. Rainfall on the 4th was mainly confined to the Riverside and San Diego County mountains, with amounts of one-tenth to one-half inch in general, and up to 1.5 inches under the heaviest cells in San Diego County. Flooding was reported along Interstate 15 north of Victorville and along National Trails Highway, as well SR 247 washed out at Reche Road, north of Yucca Valley. Activity on the 5th was concentrated farther north in the San Bernardino County mountains, upper deserts and Coachella Valley. Cells in these areas generally produced amounts of one-third of an inch, to just over one inch of rain, with locally higher amounts in the higher mountain locations. Over the two days, a spotter in Onyx Peak reported over 3 inches of rain and damage to dirt roads on their property. Thunderstorm winds also damaged two structures near Yucaipa, damaging the roof of one and collapsing the other completely.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water, 4 to 6 inches deep in places, along Indian Canyon Drive near Palm Springs Station Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low from Baja cut underneath a large area of seasonably strong high pressure aloft, tapping into lingering monsoonal moisture to produce showers and thunderstorms over the mountains and deserts, as well as a few along the coastal areas, with heavy rain at times. The activity on the 2nd consisted of elevated thunderstorms with lightning along the coast during the morning and a few thunderstorms over the San Bernardino County mountains. Rain and rapid cooling in one of these storms resulted in several bicyclists being treated for hypothermia during the Tour de Big Bear race. This elevated convection became intense and transitioned into numerous strong thunderstorms on the 3rd, focusing more on the mountains and deserts and closing several roadways due to flooding. Rainfall of 2 to 4 inches occurred in less than 3 hours across steep terrain in the San Bernardino County mountains. The hardest hit areas were Mt Baldy, Forest Falls and Oak Glen where numerous debris flows occurred causing road damage and closures. Incident Command Posts were set up at both Mt Baldy and Valley of the Falls. A weather station in Mt Baldy reported 4 inches of rain in less than 2 hours. Swift water rescues were performed in Mt Baldy along the LA County line. There was also a large area of 1 to 2.5 inches of rain in low-lying areas and deserts, including 2.73 inches in one hour at the Borrego ALERT gage. The Fish Creek RAWS in the San Diego County desert recorded 2.77 inches of rain in one hour, resulting in moderate flooding and the subsequent closure of Fish Creek Road through August 8th. Heavy rain west of the mountains produced flash flooding in Redlands and Ramona. A large sink hole developed in Redland due to heavy rainfall. San Bernardino County was the hardest hit with flash flooding, with 25 homes damaged and approximately $11 million in damage county-wide for this event. Full storm surveys were done from Mill Creek near Forest Falls, to Oak Glen, to Lytle Creek and through out Mt Baldy on August 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reports roadway flooding on Danbury Street in Cabazon. Flood water, rocks, mud, and debris flowing down the street. The roadway is impassable due to boulders and mud blocking the street.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low from Baja cut underneath a large area of seasonably strong high pressure aloft, tapping into lingering monsoonal moisture to produce showers and thunderstorms over the mountains and deserts, as well as a few along the coastal areas, with heavy rain at times. The Fish Creek RAWS in the San Diego County desert recorded 2.77 inches of rain in one hour, resulting in moderate flooding and the subsequent closure of Fish Creek Road through August 8th. Full storm surveys were done from Mill Creek near Forest Falls, to Oak Glen, to Lytle Creek and through out Mt Baldy on August 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across portions of central Riverside county during the late morning hours on August 3rd, and they produced locally heavy rainfall which led to flash flooding. Some of the more significant flooding occurred along the Interstate 10 corridor to the south of the Cottonwood Visitor's Center. According to the California Department of Highways, at approximately 1327PST, flash flooding spread dirt and debris onto the roadway at exit 162 on Interstate 10 and the Frontage Road. The roadway was also flooded, approximately 9 miles to the southwest of the Cottonwood Visitor's Center.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across portions of central Riverside county during the late morning hours on August 3rd, and they intensified into the early afternoon, producing very heavy rainfall. Rain rates were in excess of 2 inches per hour at times, and the heavy rain produced flash flooding affecting towns such as Eagle Mountain, Desert Center, Cottonwood Visitor's Center and Chiriaco Summit. Flash Flooding was also observed along the Interstate 10 corridor from Desert Center westward past Chiriaco Summit. Locally heavy rain flooded roads, spread dirt and debris onto area highways and led to road closures. Eagle Mountain road was closed as the heavy rain raised up asphalt and washed it away near mile marker 192. Multiple Flash Flood Warnings were issued for central Riverside county due to the heavy rain and observed flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across portions of central Riverside county during the late morning hours on August 3rd, and they intensified into the early afternoon. The storms produced heavy rains which led to flash flooding; the most significant flooding affected the Interstate 10 corridor in the area around Desert Center. Flash Flood Warnings were issued for a substantial portion of central Riverside county during the early afternoon hours. According to California Department of Highways personnel, flash flooding 4 miles southeast of Desert Center closed Eagle Mountain road at Mile Marker 192 on Interstate 10. The heavy rain raised up and washed away asphalt on the highway, and spread mud and debris across all of the lanes. This occurred at approximately 1409PST. Also, at 1402PST, flash flooding occurred in Desert Center; State Route 177 was flooded at Mile Marker 105 on Interstate 10 and vehicles were unable to pass. This information was also reported from the Department of Highways. Fortunately, no injuries or accidents were reported due to the flash flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across portions of central Riverside county during the late morning hours on August 3rd, and they intensified into the early afternoon, producing very heavy rainfall. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roadway washed out near the intersection of Box Canyon Road / 66th ave. Road closure required.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low from Baja cut underneath a large area of seasonably strong high pressure aloft, tapping into lingering monsoonal moisture to produce showers and thunderstorms over the mountains and deserts, as well as a few along the coastal areas, with heavy rain at times. The activity on the 2nd consisted of elevated thunderstorms with lightning along the coast during the morning and a few thunderstorms over the San Bernardino County mountains. Rain and rapid cooling in one of these storms resulted in several bicyclists being treated for hypothermia during the Tour de Big Bear race. This elevated convection became intense and transitioned into numerous strong thunderstorms on the 3rd, focusing more on the mountains and deserts and closing several roadways due to flooding. Rainfall of 2 to 4 inches occurred in less than 3 hours across steep terrain in the San Bernardino County mountains. The hardest hit areas were Mt Baldy, Forest Falls and Oak Glen where numerous debris flows occurred causing road damage and closures. Incident Command Posts were set up at both Mt Baldy and Valley of the Falls. A weather station in Mt Baldy reported 4 inches of rain in less than 2 hours. Swift water rescues were performed in Mt Baldy along the LA County line. There was also a large area of 1 to 2.5 inches of rain in low-lying areas and deserts, including 2.73 inches in one hour at the Borrego ALERT gage. The Fish Creek RAWS in the San Diego County desert recorded 2.77 inches of rain in one hour, resulting in moderate flooding and the subsequent closure of Fish Creek Road through August 8th. Heavy rain west of the mountains produced flash flooding in Redlands and Ramona. A large sink hole developed in Redland due to heavy rainfall. San Bernardino County was the hardest hit with flash flooding, with 25 homes damaged and approximately $11 million in damage county-wide for this event. Full storm surveys were done from Mill Creek near Forest Falls, to Oak Glen, to Lytle Creek and through out Mt Baldy on August 4th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: USGS gage in the Perris Valley storm drain at Nuevo Road showed a spike from 8.68 ft to 14.94 ft. by 2100 PST. The initial rise of 3 ft. occurred in less than 30 minutes. Flash flood duration was 2 hours 15 minutes. Another USGS gage on the Santa Ana River at Arlington jumped from 5.66 ft to 10.31 ft over 2 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The atmosphere across Joshua Tree National Park was especially moist and unstable on August 12th, and as a result a Flash Flood Watch was issued for the park beginning shortly after noon and continuing into the evening hours. Scattered thunderstorms with heavy rain developed across the park during the late morning hours, and they persisted into the afternoon. Rainfall rates approaching 2 inches per hour were observed with the stronger storms, and as a result flash flooding developed in the early afternoon. At about 1400PST, the park service's chief ranger reported that several roads were closed in the area around Lost Horse-Keys View. No injuries were reported due to the flash flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Conditions across eastern Riverside county were especially favorable for the formation of thunderstorms on August 12th, and as a result a Flash Flood Watch was issued for both Joshua Tree National Park and the eastern Deserts of Riverside county. The watch was in effect from noon until the early morning hours of August 13th. Scattered thunderstorms with heavy rain developed across portions of eastern Riverside county during the late morning and afternoon hours, which led to flash flooding. Flash flooding affected portions of Joshua Tree National Park, leading to the closure of several roads in the park.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported 1-inch hail in Menifee from an early morning thunderstorm. Local news media reported large hail cracked a vehicle windshield in Menifee from the same storm.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of elevated thunderstorms developed during the morning of the 20th over the ocean and along the coast ahead of an approaching upper-level low. Dynamic lift and monsoonal moisture led to further destabilization and increasing storm intensity with time. The initial band moved inland and organized thunderstorms with prolific lightning persisted over the Inland Empire and Riverside County mountains. The coastal and valley locations of San Diego and Riverside Counties received anywhere from a few hundredths of an inch of rain to one-half of an inch, with the greatest amounts in the Inland Empire and northern San Diego County valleys. The upper low moved across San Diego and Imperial Counties on the 21st, producing intense thunderstorms over the mountains and deserts, as well as a significant dust storm that moved up the Coachella Valley. The mountain locations of San Diego and Riverside Counties received up to one-half of an inch of rain, while the San Diego County deserts received up to 1.30 inches. One-inch hail was reported with thunderstorms in Nuevo and Mount Laguna/Pine Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported hail up to one inch in Nuevo from a thunderstorm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported lightning struck and ignited fires in two palm trees near the community college. The fires were put out. Lightning also struck the technology building on campus, knocking out power.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reports a dust storm producing quarter mile visibility in Cathedral City, with winds estimated at 15-20 mph. A haboob in Palm Springs felled a tree onto a pickup truck containing a man who was injured and taken to the hospital. Peak wind speeds at the nearby Palm Springs ASOS were 40 mph at that time. The dust storm then proceeded down the Coachella Valley, reaching the Thermal Airport, whose ASOS reported one-quarter mile visibility in dust and 40 knot wind gusts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported road washing out at Cedar Avenue in Hemet, as well as flooding along Highway 74 at 1st Street across all lanes of 74. Also flooding was reported at Palm and 1st, with knee-deep water. The Hemet Valle Vista alert gage recorded 2.06 inches of rain over the past hour. A few miles east on Highway 74, an off-road vehicle was stuck in a flash flood, as well as another party of 2 were stuck in a house and couldn't cross the road due to water. County Roads closed Highway 74 1.5 miles from the ranger station at Doe Canyon Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weakening Hurricane Norbert helped draw significant moisture into southwest California on the 7th. Daytime heating utilized this moisture to set off scattered thunderstorms with heavy rain at times, mainly in Riverside and San Diego Counties. Local rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches fell over the city of Riverside, San Bernardino and Hemet, while the mountains in that county saw up to six tenths of an inch, near Sky Valley. Early morning thunderstorms on the 8th drenched parts of the the Coachella Valley which received one-third of an inch up to just over 3 inches near the lower foothill in Thousand Palms, and Bear Creek in La Quinta. Rainfall rates were up to 2 inches per hour at times, producing widespread flash flooding, most notably in the Coachella Valley on September 8th. Mud and water closed several roads and stranded countless vehicles in La Quinta, Palm Desert, and Thousand Palms. Homes in La Quinta were surrounded by water. The worse hit areas were Washington Street in La Quinta and Varner Road in Thousand Palms. Moving water was a deep as 3 feet on roads and 4 to 5 feet of standing water submerged vehicles and mud was several feet high on Varner Road. A complete storm survey was done in Riverside City and in the Coachella Valley.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS survey found numerous trees downed by high winds from wet microburst. Most trees were snapped and a couple were uprooted. Trees blocked a couple roadways in residence just east of Chicago avenue. A couple trees were 2 to 3 feet in diameter. The same area had considerable flood damage to a sidewalk and concrete drainage ditch.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported the slow lane of Highway 60 at Main Street under at least 2 feet of water with several vehicles stuck in the water. CHP also reported one lane of the northbound University on-ramp to Interstate 215 is flooded. Also, all lanes of northbound Interstate 215 are flooded, except the HOV lane. Spotter 217 reported several locations flooded along Iowa Avenue in Riverside, near UC Riverside. Iowa Avenue at Center Street, Marlborough Street, and several other spots were under a foot or more of water, running up over the gutters and curbs. CHP also reported a woman stuck in her vehicle on the 14th Street on-ramp to eastbound SR 91. Several vehicles were also stuck in approximately 4 feet of water at the railroad crossing on 14th Street. CHP shut down both sides of the road there.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: California Highway Patrol reported the canal at 66th Avenue and Harrison Street ruptured and completely flooded the intersection. The intersection was closed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reports flooding and debris in all lanes on Dillon road and North Indian Canyon Drive. Starting at 0345 PST, the road started to flood with mud and water up to 4 inches deep.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported 3 vehicles stuck in water, one of which has water up over the tires. Varner Road and Bob Hope Drive are closed. Two other vehicles stuck in water at Varner Road and Date Palm Drive. CHP reported heavy flooding in the center divide and #1 lane of Interstate 10 westbound. CHP reported 6 vehicles stuck in water on Ramon Road at Chimayo Road, with water covering the tires of at least one of the vehicles. CHP reported a stalled vehicle partially in the roadway and stuck in water on Ramon Road at Thousand Palms Canyon Road. As of 0830 PST, numerous vehicles were getting stuck and blocking Thousand Palms Canyon Road, so the wash was shut down at Frances, just east of Thousand Palms Canyon Road. The ALERT gage at Thousand Palms NE recorded 1.54 inches of rain between 0530-0630 PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported Country Club Drive at Starlight Lane flooded. Avenue 42 was also completely flooded between Adams and County Club drive and was closed at this location. CHP reported a vehicle flooded out and blocking the Washington Street on-ramp to westbound Interstate 10. CHP also reported flooding of the #1 and #2 lanes of Interstate 10 westbound at Washington and Monterrey streets. Flooding signs were placed at both locations. Water 3 to 4 feet deep submerged 4 to 5 vehicles at the intersection of Washington Street and Country Club Drive. Southbound Indian Canyon Road was also closed at I-10.

The Silverado Fire began around 1009 PST on the 12th along Silverado Canyon Road in the Cleveland National Forest of the Santa Ana Mountains. The fire burned at a critical rate of spread, threatening power lines and forcing evacuations and road closures. Mandatory Evacuations ordered from 30331 Silverado Canyon east to the end of the road (fire gate), approx. 50 residences affecting approximately 220 people. The American Red Cross opened an evacuation center at 1530 at El Modena High School at 3920 East Spring Street. Orange, CA for residents who cannot return home. The Orange County Animal Care connected with residents and incident command for animal coordination. East of 30311 Silverado Canyon Road was closed. The 12kV line servicing Silverado residents was down. One pole and the downed lines needed to be replaced. There were 71 customers without power in Silverado Canyon. After burning a total of 1600 acres, the Silverado Fire was completely contained by 2000 PST on the 13th. Evacuation orders were lifted the following day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Murrieta reported 50 mph winds with a wooden fence blown down and lawn furniture thrown across the yard.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low-level moisture from Tropical Storm (formerly Hurricane) Odile streamed northward ahead of the system, underneath a ridge that was in place. The heat and moisture along a coastal sea breeze combined to produce scattered thunderstorms across the coast, beaches and inland valleys. The strongest storms were in the southern Inland Empire foothills just west of Forest Falls and near Lake Elsinore, and from Kearny Mesa to El Cajon. Rainfall totals were highly variable due to the isolated nature of the thunderstorms, but the heaviest cells on the 16th produced amounts up to one-half, to just over one inch of rain in the coast and valley locations of San Diego and Orange Counties. One to two inches of rain was reported near Lake Elsinore. The San Bernardino County mountains saw generally one-third of an inch or less. A particularly strong storm dumped just over an inch of rain, causing flooding along Balboa Avenue, near Scripps Ranch and Kearny Mesa. The winds were strong enough with these thunderstorms to down several power lines and numerous large trees (across roadways and onto vehicles) in the southern San Diego County valleys (near El Cajon and Mission Valley) and southern Riverside County valleys in Wildomar. Storm survey indicated wind speeds of 60 to 65 mph and Montgomery Field measured 56 mph. The City of San Diego reported 30 buildings damaged and the American Red Cross in Kearny Mesa had significant damage including partial roof collapse.  SDGE reported at least 12 storm-related power outages throughout the city, resulting in more than 6000 customers without power. A few thunderstorms were mountain-focused (near Julian) on the 17th as the remnants of Odile were pushed off to the east and the sea breeze boundary moved well inland.  The storms on the 17th were concentrated over the Riverside and northern San Diego County mountains, generating amounts of one-half of an inch or less. Storm surveys were completed in Wildomar and Kearny Mesa into Mission Valley. Riverside County storm damage was reported at nearly 8 million dollars from the September 7-8 and the 16th events.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain resulted in 2 inches of flowing water across Bundy Canyon Road and Harvest Way east.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The El Cariso mesonet station recorded a wind gust of 48 mph from a thunderstorm in the area. Downwind of this station, CHP reported a tree falling onto a power line on Grand Avenue in Lake Elsinore, blocking traffic. Wind damage was also reported at Elsinore High School, with power lines down and some minor flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across portions of the eastern Riverside County deserts during the evening hours on September 16th, and they produced locally heavy rainfall with peak rain rates at least as high as 1.5 inches per hour. The heavy rain led to brief flash flooding along highway 177, about 10 miles to the northeast of Desert Center. According to local law enforcement, the highway was closed for a short time due to high water running over the road. After the thunderstorms dissipated, the high water quickly subsided. There were no reports of stranded motorists or injuries due to the flash flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed across portions of the eastern deserts of Riverside County during the evening hours on September 16th. A few of the storms produced locally heavy rainfall with peak rain rates reaching at least as high as 1.5 inches per hour. The heavy rain affected locations from Desert Center eastward to Blythe, and caused brief flash flooding which affected motorists on highway 177 near Desert Center. No injuries were reported due to the flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Whitewater RAWS measured a peak gust of 59 mph between 0050 and 0150 PST on the 27th. Winds had gusted in the mid to upper 50s for the past 2 hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A trough of low pressure moved inland over central California, bringing strong onshore flow to southern California and resulting in strong and gusty west to southwest winds in the mountains and deserts of Riverside County during the early morning of the 27th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Sill Hill SDGE mesonet site between 0330-0830 PST on the 4th, with a several gusts over 60 mph. The peak gust of 69 mph was recorded between 0625-0655 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of high pressure aloft became established over the eastern Pacific, with surface high pressure over the Great Basin, resulted in offshore flow (Santa Ana winds). The gusty easterly winds were mostly confined to the San Diego County mountains and coastal slopes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Whitewater RAWS between 1650-1750 PST and ended between 2250-2350 PST on the evening of the 15th. During this time, winds were sustained out of the west-northwest at 35-45 mph with gusts near 60, including the peak gust of 60 mph recorded between 2150-2250 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry cold front passed through the area overnight on the 15th, into the 16th, with gusty west winds. Behind the front, winds turned northeasterly (Santa Ana winds) and gusty later on the 16th, lasting through the 17th as surface high pressure built in over the Great Basin. Riverside and Orange Counties were the most affected with winds during this event, with a few reports of wind damage in the Inland Empire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Pleasants Peak SDGE mesonet between 0425-0455 PST and ended between 1059-1129 PST on the morning of the 16th. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east-northeast at 35-55 mph with gusts over 60 mph. The peak gust of 76 mph recorded between 1029-1059 PST. High winds also occurred at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0651-0951 PST on the 16th, with sustained winds out of the northeast at 35-40 mph, including the peak gust of 62 mph recorded between 0851-0951 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry cold front passed through the area overnight on the 15th, into the 16th, with gusty west winds. Behind the front, winds turned northeasterly (Santa Ana winds) and gusty later on the 16th, lasting through the 17th as surface high pressure built in over the Great Basin. Riverside and Orange Counties were the most affected with winds during this event, with a few reports of wind damage in the Inland Empire.

CZ_NAME_STR: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE (ZONE)
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong easterly winds caused damage to a roof in Eastvale, near the city of Riverside. Wind gusts were estimated around 52 mph, based on nearby observations. The Press Enterprise newspaper cited 1400 customers without power in central San Bernardino at 1022 PST on the 16th. CHP also reported power lines down northeast of Perris at 1347 PST and east of Moreno Valley at 2355 PST on the 16th.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry cold front passed through the area overnight on the 15th, into the 16th, with gusty west winds. Behind the front, winds turned northeasterly (Santa Ana winds) and gusty later on the 16th, lasting through the 17th as surface high pressure built in over the Great Basin. Riverside and Orange Counties were the most affected with winds during this event, with a few reports of wind damage in the Inland Empire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from the 17th eventually ignited the North Face Fire on the 21st, with the aid of offshore winds.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few strong thunderstorms occurred over the San Bernardino and Riverside County mountains overnight on the 21st, with several lightning strikes which started smoldering wildfires. On the 21st, with the onset of offshore winds, two areas ignited into the Strawberry Fire a few miles southwest of Lake Arrowhead, and the North Face Fire in the foothills north of Mount San Jacinto. These fires were quickly extinguished by firefighters, burning no more than a few acres.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Whitewater RAWS between 2100 PST and 0000 PST on the 23rd, with sustained winds out of the west-northwest at 35-45 mph and gusting over 60 mph. The peak gust of 63 mph was recorded between 2050-2150 PST on the 22nd.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong onshore flow from a low pressure system moving inland through northern California created gusty west winds along the desert slopes on the 22nd. Strong surface high pressure built over the Great Basin on the 23rd behind the departing upper-level trough, resulting in strong, gusty east to northeast winds (Santa Ana winds) in the mountains and on the coastal mountain slopes. The strongest gusts were focused in San Bernardino and Riverside Counties on the 22nd when winds were out of the west then shifting around to the north on the 23rd, then shifted to San Diego County as winds turned more easterly later on the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds began at the Pleasants Peak SDGE mesonet between 0629-0659 PST on the 23rd and ended between 1151-1251 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east-northeast at 35-45 mph with several gusts over 60 mph, including the peak gust of 68 mph recorded between 0629-0659 PST. High winds began at the Fremont RAWS between 0651-0751 PST on the 23rd and ended between 1151-1251 PST the same day. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east-northeast at 35-45 mph with gusts over 60 mph, including the peak gust of 67 mph recorded between 0851-0951 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong onshore flow from a low pressure system moving inland through northern California created gusty west winds along the desert slopes on the 22nd. Strong surface high pressure built over the Great Basin on the 23rd behind the departing upper-level trough, resulting in strong, gusty east to northeast winds (Santa Ana winds) in the mountains and on the coastal mountain slopes. The strongest gusts were focused in San Bernardino and Riverside Counties on the 22nd when winds were out of the west then shifting around to the north on the 23rd, then shifted to San Diego County as winds turned more easterly later on the 23rd.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported the right lanes of Van Buren closed due to flooding.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific storm brought moderate to heavy rain and flash flooding to the region from the 2nd through the 4th. Two-day rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were recorded west of the mountains, while the southern slopes of the San Bernardino County mountains saw up to 5 inches of rain (isolated amount of 14.5 inches at Yucaipa Ridge). The heavy rain caused countless instances of flooding, with mud, debris and water closing several roadways and stranding vehicles. Snow levels remained above 8000 feet, so no snow accumulation was observed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Desert Sun reports that Gene Autry trail...Indian Canyon Drive...Araby Drive...and Vista Chino were closed due to flooding from water rushing down the Whitewater basin from heavy rains over Yucaipa. At the Snow Creek stream gage in Whitewater at 1830 PST the 2nd, the flow peaked at 157 cfs.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported vehicles stuck in mud with debris 10 feet high on both sides of Soboba Road, which was made a hard closure. A spotter reported a swift water rescue on Soboba Road west of Lake Park in San Jacinto. Three people were rescued and all were unharmed. CHP also reported flooding and a mudslide near Gilman Springs Road and Sublette Road, as well as a BMW sedan stuck in water at Cornell Street and Thornton Ave.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP and ABC 7 news reported Highway 74 between Dartmouth and Columbia closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: CHP reported that the road needs to be closed due to flooding at Rancho California Road and Anza Road.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific storm brought moderate to heavy rain and flash flooding to the region from the 2nd through the 4th. Two-day rainfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were recorded west of the mountains, while the southern slopes of the San Bernardino County mountains saw up to 5 inches of rain (isolated amount of 14.5 inches at Yucaipa Ridge). The heavy rain caused countless instances of flooding, with mud, debris and water closing several roadways and stranding vehicles. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A debris flow of rocks and mud several inches deep covered Highway 91 in Corona. All east-bound lanes were closed at 0200 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak, upper-level trough of low pressure moved through the West on the 16th, with scattered showers and high elevation snow. Showers lingered through the night, before a second, stronger trough moved through the region on the 17th. Showers increased in coverage and intensity with the second trough, behind a leading line of strong thunderstorms, with scattered thunderstorms behind it. Significant lightning activity occurred with this initial, organized line of thunderstorms between approximately 2200 PST on the 16th and 0400 PST on the 17th. Post-frontal showers continued, with a few reports of small hail, and a funnel cloud at Riverside March Field. Two-day rainfall totals varied widely with the coast and valley locations receiving between one-tenth and almost one inch of rain, but most saw between one-quarter and three-quarters of an inch. Coastal mountain slope locations received up to 1.3 inches of rain, while the deserts ranged from a few hundredths of an inch to one-third of an inch (highest amounts in the upper deserts). Several roads were closed due to flooding in San Marcos, Spring Valley and a mud/debris flow along Highway 91 in Corona. The snow level lowered to 4500-5000 feet, with two-day accumulations of up to 4 inches below 6000 feet and up to 10 inches between 6000-8000 feet.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The March AFB AOS observer reported a cold air funnel cloud between 1153-1158 PST.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Fremont Canyon RAWS between 0051-0551 PST on the 23rd. During this time, winds were sustained out of the ENE at 30-40 mph with gusts in the 60s, including the peak gust of 67 mph, recorded between 0151-0251 PST. High winds occurred at the Pleasants Peak mesonet station between 0059-0229 PST on the 23rd. During this time, winds were sustained out of the east at 45-50 mph with gusts in the 60s, with a peak gust of 70 mph, recorded between 0129-0159 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface pressure strengthened to a 1035 mb high over the Great Basin on the 22nd, resulting in gusty Santa Ana winds through the 23rd, strongest in the early mornings of the 23rd. Winds remained strong through the 25th, but shifted around to the northwest (onshore) on the 24th ahead of an approaching low pressure system passing to the north of the area. No significant damage was reported as a result of these winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Whitewater RAWS between 2200 PST on the 24th and 0400 PST on the 25th. During this time, winds were sustained out of the WNW at 30-40 mph with gusts in the upper 50s, with a peak gust of 61 mph, recorded between 2150-2250 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface pressure strengthened to a 1035 mb high over the Great Basin on the 22nd, resulting in gusty Santa Ana winds through the 23rd, strongest in the early mornings of the 23rd. Winds remained strong through the 25th, but shifted around to the northwest (onshore) on the 24th ahead of an approaching low pressure system passing to the north of the area. No significant damage was reported as a result of these winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds occurred at the Whitewater RAWS between 0150-0350 PST on the 30th. During this time, winds were sustained out of the west-northwest at 35-40 mph with gusts in the upper 50s, including the peak gust of 59 mph recorded between 0250-0350 PST.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very cold and potent low pressure system approached southern California on the 30th with showers increasing through the day and night with a shot of very low-elevation snow. The brunt of the storm occurred during the night of the 30th and morning of the 31st. Snow levels dropped rapidly overnight down to 1500-2000 feet, with some light accumulations even down to 1000 feet. The southern Inland Empire was hardest hit with the unusually low snow, covering areas like Temecula, Lake Elsinore, and Wildomar, which caused issues all along Interstate 15 down through Valley Center. Several inches were also reported in Ranchita and Julian in San Diego County. Overall, the snow totals went as follows: 10 to 18 inches across Palomar Mountain to Julian, 6 to 9 inches from Warner Springs to Julian in San Diego County, 2 to 4 inches from Temecula to Wildomar and Lake Elsinore in the southern Inland Empire, and 4 to 8 inches across Highway 74 and Horsethief canyon in the Santa Ana Mountains. The snow resulted in several road closures, including Highway 74 and Highway 18, stranded vehicles and chain controls on the roads that remained open. Rainfall totals below the snow level generally ranged from .25-1.25 inches, with no significant flooding reported. Thunderstorms also occurred with the leading edge of the cold front from Oceanside and Carlsbad to La Mesa with hail up to one-half inch diameter. Strong winds also accompanied this system with several reports of damage. Most gusts were sub-warning criteria, though a few stations recorded gusts over 60 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24 hour snowfall of 2-8 inches was reported by the public near Idyllwild.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter just northwest of Lake Elsinore reported 6 inches of snow at 1400 feet causing widespread damage to trees with many limbs broken. CHP reported Interstate 15 impacted by snow with 1-2 at the Clinton Keith Road exit. The Baxter Road off-ramp was closed due to snow accumulations where cars are stuck in snow. Bundy Canyon Road off-ramp Was completely snowed in with several vehicles stuck in the snow. A spotter reported Interstate 15 shutdown at Wildomar with 8-10 inches estimated at elevation of 1400 ft. A member of the public reported a 24 hour snowfall of 5 inches reported near Lake Matthews.
